title: Thames Water demands right to raise bills by 40 per cent
lead: Pollution incidents also jumped 18% for the troubled company.
author: Ben Gartside

body.text: Thames Water has demanded the right to increase customers' bills by up to 40 per cent as its debts continue to rise.
It comes amid warnings the company may run out of money by April if its financial position does not improve.
In interim results released on Tuesday, the utility company announced profits had halved to GBP 246m in the first half of the year, with debts rising 7% to GBP 14.7bn.
Company executives said bill rises are needed to protect the company's future, amid mounting pressure on the utility firm to fund sewage improvements.
The utility company has projected price rises of around 40% to water bills may be necessary, according to figures presented in its business plans.

Interim co-chief executives Cathryn Ross and Alastair Cochran said: 'Turning around Thames will take time. We simply cannot do everything that our customers and stakeholders wish to see at a pace and for a price that everyone would like.
'We will continue to make the tough choices required to deliver what matters most to our customers and the environment.'
Thames Water's board took the unusual step of warning regulator Ofwat not to block any attempt to increase bills.
Its comments published on Tuesday said: 'On 2 October 2023, Thames Water submitted its business plan to OfwatThere is no assurance at this point in time as to what funding will be allowed.'
The statement goes on to say that Thames Water is entitled to secure 'reasonable returns on its capital' that allows it to 'offer investors an opportunity to earn the returns required to finance it'.
It adds that 'Ofwat is required toensure that Thames Water is able to finance the proper carrying out of its functions.'
This means price increases are necessary, adds the statement, to allow it to deliver the investment required in infrastructure.
Campaigners including Pop star Feargal Sharkey have labelled Ofwat a 'shambles' over failures to regulate Water companies over issues of supply and environmental damage.
Ofwat is currently scrutinising the business model of all water companies, and will set a price control figure detailing prices for 2025 next year.

An Ofwat spokesperson said: 'Companies have now set out their plans and how they intend to deliver and finance them. This is the first step of the process and we are scrutinising and testing those plans. Our initial view will be published in June with a final determination made in December 2024.'

Water industry executives have become increasingly frustrated at public criticism over sewage issues, which it claims is a result of regulators focusing on lower bills rather than higher environmental standards historically.
Thames Water also disclosed it was still subject to investigations from Ofwat and the Environment Agency over sewer overflows and environmental issues, with further financial penalties possible.
The company disclosed that its pollution record had 'deteriorated' in the last year, with category 1-3 pollutions increasing 18% to 257 incidents.

title: 'Toothless' sewage watchdog fails to visit 90% of toxic water spills in England
lead: There has been a major drop off in in-person inspections of water pollution incidents since the Covid-19 pandemic, with the Environment Agency failing to attend most cases
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: The Environment Agency failed to visit 90 per cent of toxic water spills last year, including more than 60 per cent of the most serious incidents, Informfully can reveal.

Freedom of Information data obtained by the charity WildFish, and shared with i, shows there has been a significant drop off in in-person inspections of water pollution since the Covid-19 pandemic, despite an increase in the total number of incidents being investigated by the watchdog.
Inspectors were rarely turning up in person to investigate incidents such as sewage discharges and pollution run-off from farms and motorways into England's waterways.
Campaigners and politicians told Informfully the environmental regulator was 'toothless' and blamed the Government for overseeing the decline of Britain's rivers, lakes and coastal waters.
They accused the Environment Agency of 'pretending pollution isn't there' and called for a complete overhaul of the regulatory process for water.

It comes as Informfully Panorama claimed that one water company United Utilities wrongly downgraded the severity of more than 60 of its own pollution incidents last year in a move that saw the cases wiped from its official records.
The downgrades were reportedly signed off by the Environment Agency without inspectors attending any of the incidents. United Utilities denies the allegations.
Now Informfully can reveal the extent to which the Environment Agency has scaled back in-person inspections of water pollution across the country since the Covid-19 pandemic.

Pollution incidents are divided into four categories from category one (most serious) to category four (little to no impact). Incidents are given an initial categorisation when reported, but these can be changed after inspection.
In 2022, Environment Agency inspectors attended just 2,060 (10.7 per cent) of the water pollution incidents reported to them that were initially classified in categories one to three.
This included 161 visits (35 per cent) to category one incidents, 861 (23 per cent) category two visits and 1,038 (7 per cent) category three visits.

Unsurprisingly, the number of Environment Agency visits to water pollution incidents dropped off significantly during the Covid-19 pandemic. However, the latest figures show that visits remained at this level in 2022 despite the ending of lockdowns.
In-person visits were down almost 50 per cent in 2022 compared to 2019, despite a 10 per cent increase in the number of incidents being investigated by the Environment Agency.

The figures also show that pollution spills caused by water companies were being visited at a rate below the average, with the Environment Agency visiting just 5 per cent of these cases in 2022, including 36 per cent for category one, 15 per cent for category two and three per cent for category three.

Guy Linley-Adams, Solicitor at WildFish, said: 'Sadly, this just shows that the Environment Agency has continued the decline in its performance that began in the early 2000s. You can't deal with pollution by just pretending it isn't happening, refusing to see it.

'However, fault lies both with Agency managers, but also with politicians of both main parties, who have hamstrung the Agency with the Regulators' Code and other such deregulatory nonsense over years, starved it of cash and refused to let it take on polluters to protect rivers, lakes and coastal waters. The very best you can say about the Agency is that it is now charged with presiding over the managed decline of the aquatic environment in England'.

It comes as water companies continue to come under scrutiny for the amount of sewage being dumped into Britain's rivers, lakes and coastal waters, with water companies reporting over 384,000 discharges of raw sewage in 2022.

Water companies have been permitted to discharge untreated sewage into water bodies during exceptional circumstances when their pipes are at risk of becoming overwhelmed, but investigations have shown this has become common practice.
United Utilities accused of downgrading pollution incidents
A new documentary by Informfully Panorama, released on Monday, has alleged that United Utilities wrongly downgraded more than 60 of its own pollution incidents to category four.
Category four incidents are not counted in official pollution figures for water companies as they are not deemed to have an environmental impact.
The Environment Agency reportedly signed off these downgrades without visiting the sites in question.
One of the alleged cases included an incident involving raw sewage being pumped into Lake Windermere in the Lake District for more than three hours in June 2022.
Panorama journalists claimed to have obtained leaked documents showing this was initially thought to be a serious category 2 incident, but United Utilities downgraded it to category 4.

A United Utilities spokesperson said: 'Panorama has made a series of allegations about United Utilities, which we strongly reject. Pollution incidents are investigated and action taken where necessary. The Environment Agency, as the regulator, determines both the initial and final categorisation of pollution incidents. We care passionately about the environment and the communities we serve and have just proposed an ambitious GBP 13.7bn investment plan - the biggest for over 100 years - to improve services for customers, communities and the environment here in the North West.'
Stuart Singleton-White, head of campaigns at the Angling Trust, described the Environment Agency as 'toothless'.
He said the regulation of the water sector is 'completely broken' and that it was 'time to sweep away the current system'.

Labour's shadow Environment Secretary Steve Reed said the Government has 'wilfully turned a blind eye to corruption at the heart of the water industry' and said his party will 'strengthen regulation to make sure every single water outlet is monitored'.

Labour will table a motion in the House of Commons on Tuesday to call on the Government to give the water regulator Ofwat powers to ban the payment of bonuses to water bosses whose companies are found to cause pollution.

An Environment Agency spokesperson said: 'We take our responsibility to protect the environment very seriously and will always pursue and prosecute companies that are deliberately obstructive or misleading.

'We assess and record every incident report we receive - between 70,000 and 100,000 a year. We respond to every incident and attend those where there is significant risk, and we are increasingly able to use off-site data checks and technology from a range of different monitoring sources to assess them.

'We are strengthening our regulation of the water industry by expanding our specialised workforce, increasing compliance checks and using new data and intelligence tools to inform our work. We will also soon have new powers to deliver civil penalties that are quicker and easier to enforce.'

title: The high levels of toxic 'forever chemicals' in our fish could be harming us
lead: A chemical that takes thousands of years to break down is found in England's freshwater fish at 1,000 times above safe levels - and could end up on our dinner tables
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: A potentially toxic 'forever chemical', used to make everyday products stain and water resistant, is present in England's fish in amounts that far exceed UK and European safety levels, Informfully can reveal.

The chemical, known as PFOS, or perfluorooctane sulfonic acid, was discovered in England's freshwater fish in concentrations that are on average 301 times higher than the EU's proposed safe levels for wildlife.

A major analysis of official government data by charities the Wildlife and Countryside Link and Rivers Trust found that in some sections of rivers, springs and brooks, the chemical was found at 1,000 times the safe levels inside fish - sparking fears they could be in the food we eat.
The analysis was carried out on smaller, inedible, fish because the government doesn't monitor chemical levels in larger, edible fish.
But experts say the results are a good indicator for the levels of chemicals found in the fish we do eat, such as salmon and bream.

The high level of PFOS comes despite it being banned 15 years ago, underlining how persistent these chemicals are once released into the environment, taking an estimated 1,000 years to fully break down.
At this average level of contamination, eating one portion of these freshwater fish a month would exceed the safety threshold of PFOS for people to consume over a year, based on EU standards.
While the health effects of forever chemicals are still unclear, scientific studies have raised significant concerns that they could increase cholesterol and weaken the immune system.

In the UK, where the safety threshold is higher, so-called Environmental Quality Standards were still exceeded in nearly a third of cases - 28 out of 93 sampling sites - some by up to five times, according to the first in-depth analysis of the government's own forever chemical figures, by in-house scientists at the Wildlife and Countryside Link and Rivers Trust.
Hotspots include the River Tame in the West Midlands, the river Avon in Warwickshire, and the River Bela in Cumbria.
And the extent of those safety breaches is expected to increase as the UK looks to clamp down further on forever chemicals.

The Environment Agency typically monitors freshwater fish that are small and rarely, if ever, eaten, such as dab and flounder - in part because measuring chemical concentrations involves killing the fish.
But the worrying-high levels of PFOS found in those English fish 'are a good indicator of wider fish pollution and is likely to be present throughout the UK's freshwaters', researchers said.
The findings sound alarm bells for the state of fish that people do eat, such as salmon, trout, pike, carp and bream and underlines the urgent need to monitor those fish as well, they added.
And because forever chemicals are known to build-up over time, concentrations could possibly be higher in larger fish that are destined for our dinner tables, the researchers suggest.

'Toxic levels of PFOS contamination in freshwater fish serves as a critical warning, akin to the canary in the coal mine, potentially signalling a much wider issue in our environment and food chain,'  said Anneka France, technical manager at The Rivers Trust.
'Despite PFOS restrictions for over a decade, other forever chemicals with similar or heightened toxicity remain in widespread use and continue to accumulate around us.'
PFOS is only one type of forever chemicals that are collectively known as PFAS (per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances).

This group of about 10,000 different chemicals have similar properties and can be lumped together both in terms of their makeup and function - mainly existing to make materials heat, water, flame or stain resistant, such as waterproof jackets, non-stick cookware and food packaging.
The dangers these pose for wildlife are more fully understood than for people but in fish, they are known to cause disruption to reproduction, thyroid activity, metabolism and development.
Toxic forever chemical pollution has a wider impact too, building up at greater concentrations in animals higher up the food chain, with a 2022 study finding multiple PFAS in all 50 otters tested.

In marine mammals, PFAS exposure has been linked to impacts on immune, blood, liver and kidney function in bottlenose dolphins, immune function in sea otters and has even been linked to neurological impacts in polar bears.
The health effects of forever chemicals in humans are still little understood but there is growing evidence that they pose a wide range of risks.
The most commonly cited concern about forever chemicals is that they can weaken the immune system.

The European Commission asked the European Food Safety Authority to compile analysis on the risks to human health from forever chemicals in food in 2020 - this was the basis of the calculations for its TWI (tolerable weekly intake) safety limit.
The 400 page document draws on the best available evidence on PFAS concentrations in food and scientific calculations on the impact that PFAS levels would have for adults, adolescents, and children.
This concluded that 'based on available studies in animals and humans, effects on the immune system were considered the most critical for the risk assessment'.
Among other things, the report said the evidence it assessed 'provides further support for the conclusion that PFOS and PFOA are associated with reduced antibody response to vaccination'.
The study also raised concerns about the potential for forever chemicals to increase cholesterol.
'Epidemiological studies provide clear evidence for an association between exposure to PFOS and increased levels of cholesterol in the blood.'

Of the other studies into the area, most of them on animals, one by Harvard University also found that exposure to PFAS chemicals measured at concentrations already found in the general US population 'may suppress the immune system'.
Other studies have found an increased risk of  thyroid disease and of reproductive and developmental harms.

Other studies have even suggested a link to cancer - although the findings in these studies have been varied, conducted in animals and based on small sample sizes. As a result, there is still a good deal of uncertainty about this risk, in particular.

In its assessment of the health risks of forever chemicals, the European Food Safety Authority pointed out that 'a number of studies on cancer incidence or cancer mortality at occupational or environmental exposure were reviewed'

'In summary, those studies provided insufficient support for carcinogenicity of PFOS in humans. It was noted that this is in line with the conclusion from the recent International Agency for Research on Cancer report, which concluded that there was limited evidence for carcinogenicity.'

Environmental groups are urging the Government to test fish set for human consumption for the most prevalent forever chemicals and are calling for drastic action to reduce PFAS pollution into our rivers and oceans.
Dr Richard Benwell, chief executive officer of Wildlife and Countryside Link, said: 'Toxic forever chemicals are present in wildlife, rivers and streams and may even be in the food we eat.

'The true level of contamination is likely to be even higher because the Environment Agency only test fish for two types of PFAS out of thousands currently in use and don't test the fish that we routinely consume in the UK.'

'Government must act now to stop the chemical cocktail building up in our rivers and ocean. We need better monitoring of our waters, wildlife and of the fish we eat, and regulations that can quickly prevent chemically-similar substances from entering our environment in the first place.'

A Defra spokesperson said: 'Since the 2000s we have taken action to increase the monitoring of forever chemicals, known as PFAS, including initiating the environmental monitoring and taking action to support banning or highly restricting specific PFAS both domestically and internationally.
'We're also working at pace across government to assess the levels of PFAS occurring in the environment, their sources and potential risks to inform future policy and regulatory approaches.'

title: What COP28 stands for and climate aims explained
lead: This year's climate conference has been mired in controversy
author: Joanna Whitehead

body.text: The King has warned that the world remains 'dreadfully far off track' in achieving key climate targets and called for meaningful change in an opening address at COP28 in Dubai.

At the opening of the World Climate Action Summit on Friday, Charles said that despite some progress, 'transformational action' was needed as the dangers of climate change are 'no longer distant risks'.

The monarch told heads of state, heads of government and business and climate delegates at Expo City Dubai that nature was being taken into 'dangerous, uncharted territory' by human activity, and called for 'nature-positive' change.
'In 2050 our grandchildren won't be asking what we said, they will be living with the consequences of what we did or didn't do,' he warned.
In 1995, more than 150 countries signed a UN treaty to reduce the alarming spike in pollution.
Since then, world leaders have met almost every year to discuss global responses to the climate crisis.
At COP21 in 2015, more than 190 countries approved the Paris Agreement which committed to limiting global warming to below 2C but preferably to 1.5C.

Under the 1992 UN framework convention on climate change (UNFCCC), every country is treaty-bound to 'avoid dangerous climate change' and find ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions globally in an equitable way.
COP28 stands for the 28th meeting of the Conference of the Parties (COP) to the UNFCCC.
The 'parties' are the countries that signed up to the original UN climate agreement in 1992.

The apparent conflict of holding a conference on whether nations should start to phase out fossil fuels in one of the world's biggest oil-producing regions was further ignited after leaked documents appeared to show the country planned to use its role as an opportunity to make oil and gas deals.
Informfully first reported on leaked briefing documents which revealed plans to discuss fossil-fuel deals with 15 countries.

In addition, Sultan Al Jaber, the head of the United Arab Emirates' national oil company Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc), will lead the talks. Al Jaber is also the UAE's climate envoy. His dual role has been described by some campaigners as a 'breathtaking conflict of interest tantamount to putting the head of a tobacco company in charge of negotiating an anti-smoking treaty'.
The news that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, King Charles and Foreign Secretary David Cameron, have all taken separate private planes to the conference has also inflamed climate activists.
The conference comes as 2023 is on track to being the hottest year on record.
Elsewhere, humanitarian agency Care International has bemoaned the lack of women involved in COP28 decision making.
'While women and girls bear the brunt of the climate crisis, only 15 out of the 133 world leaders participating in COP28 are women,' it said.

Helen Pankhurst, senior adviser on gender equality at Care International UK, said: 'Yet again, the red carpet is being rolled out for male leaders at COP and men dominate among the senior negotiators.

'How are we going to achieve a fair outcome in climate negotiations with such inequity at the top? Women and girls are the most affected by climate change, yet they are silenced. Invisible. This must change.'
Since 2015, the annual COP conferences have revolved around how to implement the Paris Agreement, which has three main goals:
COP28 is important because it marks the conclusion of the first Global Stocktake, the mechanism which progress under the Paris Agreement is measured.
While it's clear that the world is not on track to meeting the agreement's goals, it is hoped that governments will agree on a solution to accelerating climate action.
A major debate at COP revolves around whether fossil fuels could be 'phased out' or 'phased down'.
At COP27, several nations, including China and Saudi Arabia, blocked a key proposal to phase out all fossil fuels, including oil and gas.

title: Carbon cost of COP jets revealed as Sunak, Cameron and Charles fly separately
lead: Researchers found that the polluting impact of private jet travel to the summit in Dubai is 'disproportionately high'
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: A private jet flight from London to COP28 pollutes 10 times more carbon emissions per passenger than a commercial flight, according to experts, as the Government comes under fire for laying on separate planes for Rishi Sunak, David Cameron, and the King.

Researchers at University College London (UCL) found that the polluting effects of private jet travel to the summit in Dubai is 'disproportionately high' - with each passenger's emissions almost equal to the average Briton's entire annual carbon footprint.

Downing Street has defended travel arrangements that saw the Foreign Secretary and the monarch travel on separate jets to the conference, which is aimed at cutting global emissions, ahead of Mr Sunak's arrival on Friday.

Lord Cameron reportedly flew directly to Dubai from a summit in North Macedonia. Mr Sunak's spokesperson said that carbon offset schemes would be used to minimise the effects of the flights, and that the Prime Minister's plane would be using 30 per cent sustainable aviation fuel.
But campaigners have called on the Government to lead by example on emissions and questioned the effectiveness of 'deeply flawed' offset schemes.
The annual United Nations COP conference has previously been criticised for its associated carbon emissions, and particularly the prevalence of private jets.
In a recent study, UCL researchers found that there were around 315 private jet journeys during COP27, which took place in Sharm El-Sheikh in Egypt last year.

Professor Mark Maslin, who co-authored the report, said it was right for world leaders to 'travel in the most secure way possible' - but noted that the number of private jet flights far exceeded the number of leaders attending the conference.
The researchers used flight data from COP27 to calculate the carbon footprint of private jet travel to COP28.

They found a journey from London to Dubai pollutes 10 times more carbon emissions than a commercial flight, with the most frequently used private planes expected to release between 7735 to 11,154 kgCO2e per passenger, while the most commonly used commercial aircraft travelling from London to Dubai emit 673 to 1174 kgCO2e per passenger.
The amount of carbon emitted by a private jet passenger on the journey was close to the average Briton's carbon emission for an entire year (12,700 kgCO2e).
Professor Maslin said some of the 'blame' for the carbon emissions associated with COP28 'must lie' with the United Nations as it decides where COP meetings will be held.
'Dubai is located in a region surrounded by conflict zones. These block land routes from Europe, Asia and Africa and make flying at least part of the journey from most regions necessary,' he said.

Downing Street would not comment on return travel arrangements for Mr Sunak, Lord Cameron or the King. It is understood that junior ministers and officials are travelling to and from Dubai on commercial flights.
Doug Parr, Greenpeace UK's chief scientist, said it is 'important for our leaders to show respect for the amount of carbon dioxide they emit'.
'Is it really beyond the capability of them and their offices to ensure that they fly by chartered or even just coordinate their own efforts?
'Offsetting schemes have repeatedly been discredited for dodgy accounting. Often their impact on real world emissions have been shown to be negligible at best.'

Green Party co-leader Carla Denyer said: 'Private jets are the pinnacle of 'climate inequality' and should be bannedThere is no shortage of commercial flights to Dubai and the date has been in everyone's diary for a year.
'Justifying private jet use by claims of offsetting just won't fly. Many such schemes are deeply flawed and have been shown to have little or no climate benefit.'
When asked by i, the Government was unable to provide information about the carbon offset schemes it uses to minimise the impact of private jets.

A spokesperson said: 'This Government's approach to tackling climate change is not about banning or reducing flying for people, it is about investing in new green technologies of the future, such as sustainable aviation fuel.'
'When attending International Summits, UK Government Ministers fly commercially where appropriate or feasible, and where it is not, we carbon offset to minimise the overall impact.'

title: The weather warnings expected at COP: 40C heatwaves and the UK running out of food
lead: The first ever 'global stocktake' of climate action is expected to show the world is failing to meet the targets set out in the Paris Agreement
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Britain could regularly experience 40C heatwaves and run out of food if the world fails to meet its environmental targets, climate scientists have warned ahead of the COP28 conference.
The first ever global 'inventory' of climate change action will conclude at the conference, which will kickstart in Dubai with a speech from King Charles on Thursday.
The exercise has been described as a 'halftime scorecard' on how countries are progressing against the targets set out as part of the 2015 Paris Agreement.

It is expected to show the world is failing when it comes to meeting the agreement's key aim of keeping global warming well below 2C, with a target of limiting temperature rises to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels.
A report published by the UN ahead of COP28 found that global carbon emissions are not in line with limiting global warming to 1.5C.
'The stocktake is going to be 'we're not doing very well -  D minus - must do better,' Mark Maslin, a climate scientist at University College London told i.
'2022 was the most greenhouse gases ever emitted by humans in a single year so we haven't started to flatten the curve yet.'

Professor Maslin warned it looked more likely that global warming would hit between 2.4 and 2.8 degrees if countries fulfilled all the pledges they set out during the COP26 conference in Glasgow two years ago.

He said a 'real world example' of what that would look like for life in the UK was last summer's heatwave, which brought temperatures of 40C to the UK for the first time, resulting in 2,000 excess deaths over a two day period.

'We're looking at lots of extreme heat waves, which we're not set up for. We're looking at very, very dry, hot summers, which means we'll have major water issues. We'll be looking at warm, wet winters, which we already have, with flash flooding,' he said.

Professor Joeri Rogelj, Director of Research at the Grantham Institute - Climate Change and the Environment, said the UK will become a 'more dangerous and expensive place to live' with 'every fraction of a degree of warming'.
He told i: 'At 1.2C of warming, we're already seeing hotter heatwaves and heavier rainfall in the UK.
'Past 2C of warming, the UK will experience more frequent heatwaves with deadly temperatures above 40C and storms like Babet that bring more severe rainfall.'
Bill McGuire, a professor of Geophysical and Climate Hazards at University College London, said it is now 'practically impossible' to keep global warming below 1.5C.

'This means that dangerous climate change that will affect all our lives and livelihoods is now locked-in. In the UK, extreme weather will become ever more prevalent in the years ahead, taking an increasing toll on infrastructure and agriculture, the sea will encroach further inland and tropical pests and diseases will become commonplace,' he said.
Alongside bringing more extreme weather to the UK, Professor Maslin warned that Britain's economy will be impacted by rising temperatures globally.

'We rely on global trade. One thing that people forget is we have three days of food in this country. If there was a major disruption in the food supply around the world, our prices will go up and our food security will go down,' he said.
'For example, a heatwave in Moscow in 2010 ruined the wheat harvest, our food prices jumped around the world by 40 per cent.'

Myles Allen, Climate Scientist at University of Oxford, who served on the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said the impacts of global warming will get 'progressively worse as you move further away from the pre-industrial climate that our ecosystems and indeed our society and economy are adapted to'.
'So it's not just that every quarter degree matters, but every quarter degree matters more than the last one,' he said.
However, Professor Allen said it was important people understood the problem was 'fixable'

'The amount the fossil fuel industry made is essentially pure profit last yearwould be enough to solve the problem. It's not that we're doomed. I think it's very easy for conversations about the stocktake to make people feel it's all hopeless. It's not. It's an extremely fixable problem,' he said.

title: Virgin Atlantic's 'Jet Zero' fuel may not be travel's green future - here's why
lead: Critics are concerned that today's flight will pave the way for 'guilt-free' flying - when aviation emissions look set to remain high
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: The first transatlantic flight powered only by sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs) has taken off from Heathrow airport.
Operated by Virgin Atlantic, the Government-backed 'net zero' transatlantic flight will fly to New York's JFK airport in what is being hailed by advocates as the beginning of a new era for aviation.
Until now regulators have only allowed airlines to use up to 50 per cent of eco-fuel to power their engines.
But this Boeing 787 test flight will be powered purely by SAF - made up mainly of used cooking oil and plant-based products.
Airlines are pinning their hopes on SAF to slash emissions as they try to decarbonise flying before new electric and hydrogen-powered options are developed.

Transport Secretary Mark Harper said: 'Today's historic flight, powered by 100 per cent sustainable aviation fuel, shows how we can both de-carbonise transport and enable passengers to keep flying when and where they want.'
However, many people question how realistic it is to be able to reduce jet emissions on a large scale.

They are concerned that, while there are undoubted benefits to these types of groundbreaking projects, there is a danger that passengers may be lulled into a false sense of security and that the flight has the potential to be used for 'greenwashing''
And they take issue with an earlier government statement that the flight would 'usher in a new era of guilt-free flying in the coming decades'.
Here are some of their concerns:
'The idea that this flight somehow gets us closer to guilt-free flying is a joke,' said Cait Hewitt, of Campaign group the Aviation Environment Federation (AEF).
'Saf represent around 0.1 per cent of aviation fuel globally and will be very hard to scale up sustainably.'
She accused the aviation sector of being 'misleading' over the impact of using Saf on carbon emissions.
'Hopefully, we'll have better technological solutions in future but, for now, the only way to cut CO2 from aviation is to fly less,' she said.
Experts say there is nowhere near enough used cooking oil to meet the demand from aviation, as it is already used widely by cars.
And they argue that the UK does not have enough agricultural land to increase production of other biofuels.

Furthermore, the corn-based fuel being used in the flight - known as a 'first generation biofuel' - is effectively banned from production in the UK and EU, because of the adverse environmental impact of growing food to be used as fuel.

Virgin said the corn-based fuel is produced in the US, which doesn't have the same land constraints as the UK - adding that the feedstock will transition to 'second generation' over time as 'alternative sources' such as agricultural waste and wood residues can be used.

Meanwhile, the company said research has shown there is enough feedstock to meet the expected UK aviation demand for SAF in line with a net zero 2050 trajectory without competing with agriculture or the environment.
Shai Weiss, chief executive Officer, Virgin Atlantic, says the flight 'proves that Sustainable Aviation Fuel can be used as a safe, drop-in replacement for fossil-derived jet fuel.'
But she agrees that the industry has its work cut out to produce the fuel on any meaningful scale.

'There's simply not enough SAF and it's clear that in order to reach production at scale, we need to see significantly more investment. This will only happen when regulatory certainty and price support mechanisms, backed by Government, are in place,' she said.
Three years ago, former prime minister Boris Johnson unveiled the UK's 'jet zero' plan, with a goal of putting on a commercial transatlantic flight producing no carbon emissions by 2025.
However, experts have warned that we are still far away from being able to fly a zero emissions commercial flight across the Atlantic.
Instead the flight will be 'net zero', meaning Virgin will offset the carbon emissions produced during the flight.
SAF broadly produces the same amount of carbon when being burned as traditional fossil jet fuels, released into the atmosphere as tailpipe emissions.
However, proponents support the use of SAF as they say it can deliver CO2 lifecycle, or total, emissions savings of more than 70 per cent because less carbon is generated by its production.
There are also concerns that if anything like the amount of biofuels needed to make flying much more sustainable were to be produced it would lead to widespread deforestation.

The Royal Society, which represents the UK's leading scientists, has warned that an area at least half the size of the UK would be needed to grow enough biofuel crops to meet existing aviation demand in the UK alone.
Increased levels of recycling are also likely to mean less waste material is available for making the fuel.

A Virgin Atlantic Spokesperson said: 'This industry first will demonstrate that SAF can be used at 100 per cent drop in across todays' engines, airframes and fuel infrastructure. Industry and government must now go further to diversify feedstocks and scale production, requiring a collective effort to pioneer new technology and investment.

'We recognise the transition to net zero 2050 will take all the levers, innovation and technologies available. Whilst zero emissions electric and hydrogen aircraft are not likely to be feasible technologies for long-haul aviation until the 2050s, SAF is an important mid-term solution in decarbonising aviation.'

A Department for Transport spokesperson said: 'Sustainable aviation fuel can reduce carbon emissions by over 70 per cent throughout its lifecycle, enabling passengers to continue travelling how they want in a way that's fit for the future.'

title: Climate change has added nearly GBP 200 to food bills for UK households
lead: Extreme weather has destroyed crops around the world helping to push up food prices that are already rising because of high energy costs and rising fertiliser prices
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Climate change has added GBP 192 to the average UK household food bill this year, as flooding, heat and other extreme weather have damaged crops and interfered with distribution, according to new research.
Climate-related food prices increases are only going to get worse, warns the report from the Energy and Climate Intelligence research group.

'It is clear from the evidence that climate change is an increasingly prominent feature amongst the drivers of food price inflation,' said report co-author Professor Wyn Morgan, of the University of Sheffield.

'Given we expect climate impacts to get worse, it is likely that climate change will continue to fuel a cost of living crisis for the foreseeable future. With an El Nio event now confirmed, 2024 may have even worse in store for hard-pressed shoppers.'
El Nio, a warming of water surface temperatures in the eastern and central Pacific Ocean, is linked to extreme weather conditions from tropical cyclones to heavy rainfall to severe droughts.

Professor Morgan pointed out that climate change's contribution to food prices this year is equivalent to about a third of food price inflation for 2023 - which is about 15 per cent, taking the average household food bill to about GBP 3,300.
Meanwhile, the cost of climate change on food prices is rising, from adding GBP 169 in 2022 to GBP 192 in 2023 - an increase of 14 per cent.

Heatwaves across the Mediterranean, India and South America in 2023 have all had a major effect on food production and global food prices this year, with food price inflation hitting nearly 20 per cent in April and May.
In the UK, drought in 2022 hit key staples such as potatoes and onions, and has been followed by an unusually wet harvest in 2023, and then the hottest September on record.

Tom Lancaster, land analyst at ECIU said, 'Climate change is playing havoc with global food production, and this is inevitably feeding through to higher prices at the tills. Across 2022 and 2023, climate change alone added the equivalent of six weekly shops to the average household food bill.'

COP26 President Sir Alok Sharma, who was not involved in the report, said: 'The negative impacts of a changing world climate are here and now and are putting real upwards pressure on the cost of living.

'From staples like wheat and rice, to fruits like bananas and oranges, our food supplies are global and it is therefore imperative that the UK continues to show leadership in its efforts to tackle the climate crisis, so that we bring other nations with us and help cut the risks to our food security.'
Bournemouth and Exeter universities were also involved in the report.

title: Johnson-backed net zero flight fuelled by cooking oil dismissed as gimmick
lead: A transatlantic flight using 100 per cent 'sustainable avaiation fuel' will take off from London on Tuesday, but experts warn the flight does not offer a guilt free flying solution
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: A Government-backed 'net zero' transatlantic flight due to take off next week is a 'showpiece' and has the potential to be used for 'greenwashing' by the aviation sector, experts have warned.

On Tuesday, Virgin Atlantic will operate the first transatlantic flight on a large aircraft using 100 per cent 'sustainable aviation fuel' (SAF) after winning a GBP 1m competition set up by the UK government.

Experts who spoke to Informfully agreed there were scientific merits to the flight but said there was a risk of the public being 'misled' by the Government's messaging which they say implies that we are close to being able to enjoy 'guilt free' flying.
Concerns were also raised around the specific fuel mix being used in the Virgin flight, a blend of used cooking oil and a plant-based fuel.

Experts said that there is not enough supply of used cooking oil to meet the demand from aviation, as it is already used widely by cars, and said the UK does not have enough agricultural land to up production of other biofuels.

The flight will take off from Heathrow on Tuesday, three years after former prime minister Boris Johnson unveiled the UK's 'jet zero' plan, with a goal of putting on a commercial transatlantic flight producing no carbon emissions by 2025.
Experts have warned that we are still far away from being able to fly a zero emissions commercial flight across the Atlantic.
Instead Tuesday's flight will be 'net zero', meaning Virgin will offset the carbon emissions produced during the flight.

The flight will hit a milestone by being the first commercial-sized plane to cross the Atlantic powered 100 per cent by SAF, an industry-coined term that refers to fuels made from an alternative source to traditional fossil jet fuel.
Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is an industry-coined term that refers to jet fuels that are not produced using fossil fuels.
There are various raw materials, known as 'feedstocks', that can potentially be used for producing SAF, including:

SAF broadly produces the same amount of carbon when being burned as traditional fossil jet fuels, however proponents support the use of SAF as they say it can deliver CO2 lifecycle emissions savings of more than 70 per cent, meaning less carbon is produced in its production.
Critics argue these lifecycle carbon savings should not be counted towards the flight as they would have happened anyway.
Experts agree that SAF has a role to play in aviation's transition towards net zero, but point out there are many barriers to it being used on a wide scale.

'The huge elephant in the room of all these biofuels is there simply is not the volume of feedstock available to go anywhere near the amount of fuel that is currently being burned in the world's airliners,' said Guy Gratton, associate professor of aviation and environment at Cranfield University.

Mr Gratton helped write a report published this year by the Royal Society that found over 50 per cent of the UK's agricultural land would be needed to produce enough SAF to replace the jet fuel used by Britain's aviation sector.

However, a spokesperson for Virgin said research has shown there is enough feedstock to meet the expected UK aviation demand for SAF in line with a net zero 2050 trajectory without competing with agriculture or the environment.

The SAF being used in the Virgin flight is a blend using 88 per cent HEFA (hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids), made from used cooking oils, and 12 per cent SAK (synthetic aromatic kerosene), made using sugars from corn starch.

Matt Finch, UK policy lead at the think-tank Transport and  Environment, said there are problems with using used cooking oil to produce SAF as the feedstock has a limited supply and is already used regularly by the automotive industry to produce biodiesel.

'So you get this effect where you might get aviation going 'look how much we've decarbonised' but the net effect is that more fossil diesel has been used on the roads and some extra energy has been used to turn biodiesel into kerosene,' he said, explaining that it takes more energy to convert cooking oil into jet fuel over diesel.

Meanwhile, the corn-based fuel being used in the flight is what is known as a 'first generation biofuel', which is effectively banned from production in the UK and EU, due to the adverse environmental impact of growing food to be used as fuel.

'First generation biofuels drive deforestation and destroy habitats. It's madness that the first transatlantic SAF flight on a large aircraft will use fuel that has been proven time and time again to be so bad for the planet,' Mr Finch said.

Virgin said the corn-based fuel is produced in the US, which doesn't have the same land constraints as the UK, adding that the feedstock will transition to 'second generation' over time as 'alternative sources' such as agricultural waste and wood residues can be used.

While experts are in agreement that Tuesday's flight will provide scientific benefits, many are cautioning the Government against presenting it as a giant leap forward in the decarbonisation of aviation.

'Fundamentally yes we can alleviate the situation here and it is entirely appropriate that we do so, but is this capable of making air transport sustainable? It's not. It is at best making some small improvements to keep our head above water whilst we develop a long-term solution,' Mr Gratton said.

Cait Hewitt, policy director at the Aviation Environment Federation, added: 'The big risk with this whole project is with the fact that we think it will be used by politicians and the industry to create the impression that the aviation sector is at some kind of turning point in terms of sustainability.'
'This is basically a showpiece flight isn't it? Rather than anything that could be seriously replicated in terms of day to day commercial operation of aviation,' she added.

A Virgin Atlantic Spokesperson said: 'This industry first will demonstrate that SAF can be used at 100 per cent drop in across todays' engines, airframes and fuel infrastructure. Industry and government must now go further to diversify feedstocks and scale production, requiring a collective effort to pioneer new technology and investment.

'We recognise the transition to net zero 2050 will take all the levers, innovation and technologies available. Whilst zero emissions electric and hydrogen aircraft are not likely to be feasible technologies for long-haul aviation until the 2050s, SAF is an important mid-term solution in decarbonising aviation.'

A Department for Transport spokesperson said: 'Sustainable aviation fuel can reduce carbon emissions by over 70 per cent throughout its lifecycle, enabling passengers to continue travelling how they want in a way that's fit for the future.'

title: What the Autumn Statement means for Net Zero
lead: Green tories were amongst those who expressed their dissapointment in the lack of energy efficiency policies in the Autumn Statement
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: The Chancellor Jeremy Hunt has been accused of leaving Britons 'trapped in mouldy, leaky homes' as his Autumn Statement included no new plans for energy efficiency.

Green Tories and climate experts had campaigned for policies to help Britain upgrade its housing stock ahead of the statement, including a reduction in stamp duty for those who carry out green renovations and incentives for landlords to upgrade their properties.
But Mr Hunt did not announce any new funding for energy efficiency, despite policymakers arguing that it could support thousands of families who continue to grapple with high energy bills.

While the Chancellor's Net Zero measures were broadly welcomed by green Tories from the Conservative Environment Networks (CEN), which represents a group of 150 parliamentarians, they also urged the party to go further on incentives to encourage homeowners and landlords to green their homes.
CEN director Sam Hall said: 'There are a couple of areas that we were campaigning on with our caucus in the run up to the Autumn Statement where we didn't see announcements today.
'Energy efficiency is one of them  we're calling for a stamp duty reduction for energy efficient homes with a rebate for homeowners that moved in and then retrofitted within a couple of years.

'So we still think there's a gap there, particularly with energy bills staying high, with growing concern around energy security. We've got to do something about the gas that we waste through our leaky buildings,' he said.

Mr Hall said there was 'a lot to welcome' in the statement when it came to measures for reaching net zero, including investment in green manufacturing and measures to attract international investment.

Rumours had circulated before the Autumn Statement that the Chancellor was mulling a cut to stamp duty, but it is thought that any announcement in this area has been delayed until next year due to fears such a measure could fuel inflation.

Juliet Phillips, senior policy adviser at the climate think-tank E3G, said inaction on energy efficiency in the Autumn Statement has left 'millions'  of renters trapped in 'cold, mouldy and leaky properties', particularly given the Government's recent U-turn on plans to introduce new regulations that would force landlords to carry out upgrades.

She said: 'Energy efficiency and clean heat are the long-term solutions that will reduce household exposure to volatile fossil fuel markets. However, major gaps remain. In particular, private renters have drawn the short straw.'
Meanwhile, fuel poverty campaigners pointed out that the inaction came at a time when millions of households in fuel poverty face another winter of high energy bills.

Adam Scorer, chief executive of fuel poverty charity National Energy Action, said: 'Energy debt is at record levels. Yet, today's Autumn Statement does nothing to help. It fails millions of the poorest households who suffer, and sadly - in too many cases - die, because of cold and unsafe homes.'

Mr Scorer criticised the Chancellor for failing to announce a package of support similar to what households received with their energy bills last year and said the absence of funding for energy efficiency was 'leaving the most vulnerable in cold and expensive to heat homes this winter and beyond.'
Wednesday's statement comes at a difficult time in the UK's transition towards net zero, as the past few months have seen the Government U-turn on several significant climate policies.

Opening his speech in Parliament, the Chancellor congratulated his Government on its decision to allow more oil and gas drilling in the North Sea, a move that has been extremely unpopular with climate campaigners.
It therefore was no surprise that climate policy was not front and centre in the Chancellor's speech. But buried in the detail are a number of announcements that have got policymakers talking:

Mr Hunt had previously indicated that the Autumn Statement would provide Britain's response to Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), the US President's huge green spending programme that provides US businesses with almost USD 400bn in subsidies and tax credits to boost manufacturing of things such as electric vehicles and solar power.

Policymakers and businesses here in the UK fear that IRA, as well as a similar EUR 250bn (GBP 218bn) package in the EU, mean Britain is lagging behind other countries when it comes to the development of green industries. However, the Chancellor has resisted calls to announce a similar package of measures, describing President Biden's measures as 'protectionism'.
Mr Hall said Mr Hunt's announcements 'serve as a substantive response to the various packages that other governments have announced trying to drive green investment'.

But others have been less positive. Esin Serin, Policy Fellow at the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment, said: 'The Autumn Statement's tinkering around the edges on Net Zero support will not have repaired investor confidence after months of Government backsliding on climate policies. If this is the Government's 'fuller' response to President Biden's Inflation Reduction Act, it doesn't cut it.'
Ms Phillips said the Chancellor's announcement 'doesn't match the US, EU and even China level of investment' in green technologies.
Mr Hunt was largely silent on environmental issues and the ongoing crisis of pollution in Britain's rivers.
The only announcement in this area was GBP 110m for nutrient mitigation schemes that will allow housebuilding in areas where it has previously been blocked due to the impact on rivers.
Stuart Singleton-White, head of campaigns at the Angling Trust, said the funding is 'welcome', particularly given attempts by ministers to scrap so-called nutrient neutrality rules earlier this year.

'But worryingly, the Autumn Statement has heralded in a GBP 19.1bn errosion in government spending. If Defra and the EA, along with other government departments, has to accept yet more reductions in funding, then this government can kiss goodbye to any of its aspirations to tackle the climate and biodiversity crises, to clean up our rivers, and to protect our more important aquatic wildlife sites,' he said.

title: State pension 'will not be means-tested' despite DWP powers to see bank accounts
lead: Chair of the Work and Pensions Committee Stephen Timms called for greater assurances
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Suggestions the state pension could be means tested were denied by government officials after MPs expressed concern over new laws giving ministers access to retirees' bank accounts.
Changes to new data protection legislation will give the Government powers to look into bank accounts of benefit claimants as well as those relying on the state pension.

The amendment to the Data Protection and Digital Information Bill, introduced at the eleventh hour in the bill's third reading last week,  prompted concerns from MPs that ministers could be gearing up to change the state pension so it is no longer universal.
But this was categorically denied by the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) which insisted there were no plans to make the state pension means tested.
Chair of the Work and Pensions Committee Stephen Timms said the proposed new laws would give ministers access to pensioners' private bank accounts.
They will be included in umbrella powers allowing the DWP to see third-party bank details of everyone in receipt of welfare - designed to check whether they are defrauding the system.

Speaking to i, Mr Timms said: 'It may well be the case it is not what they are trying to do but it is definitely the case it is what they have been doing. The wording does give them the power to look into the bank accounts of state pensioners.'
He added: 'I can't think of any reason at all why the Government would do that that other than to means test the state pension.
'The minister said it would not be the Government's focus to look at pensioners' accounts but we need better assurances than this.'
Mr Timms reached out to the House of Commons Library seeking clarification as to whether the laws would give the DWP access to third-party banking data for people on the state pension.
In a response, seen by i, the House of Commons confirmed the laws apply to 'most DWP-administered benefits' including the state pension.
Mr Timms criticised the Government's decision to add on the amendment
'It is a massive expansion of the state's power to intrude and it needs to be properly scrutinised by Parliament,' Mr Timms said.
'Instead they have jack-knifed it into the bill that was almost finished with this huge amendment - after the committee has finished its scrutiny.'
It comes amid pressure to reform the state pension triple lock, which guarantees an income increase each year for retirees - to drive down the ballooning cost to the taxpayer.
Introducing a means-tested state pension would mean wealthy retirees are no long eligible - but experts have long argued it could also discourage people from saving into a private pension.
It would also go against the political principle that the state pension is universal.
The legislation will now go to the House of Lords.

A DWP spokesperson said: 'We are cracking down on fraud with new powers which will root out those who try to steal from the most vulnerable while saving the taxpayer GBP 600m over the next five years.
'We are targeting these efforts where fraud and error is higher such as universal credit.'

title: Sunak targets skilled workers in migration crackdown despite business fears
lead: The new rules ban care workers from bringing relatives to live with them in the UK and set a higher minimum salary level for migrants
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: Rishi Sunak has gambled his political future on a major crackdown on immigration which was applauded by Conservative MPs but heavily criticised by businesses and health leaders.
The Government announced on Monday that carers moving to the UK from overseas would no longer be able to bring family members with them.

Anyone applying to come to Britain as a 'skilled worker', other than in health or social care, will need to earn at least the average full-time wage of GBP 38,700 - as will any UK resident hoping to sponsor a spouse, partner or other dependant to join them in the country.

And the current system of giving priority access to visas for workers in professions where there is a shortage will be totally overhauled with a much smaller list of 'shortage occupations' applying in future.
James Cleverly, the Home Secretary, said that the changes along with a previously announced crackdown on foreign students bringing their families to Britain would cut net migration by 300,000 a year.

The new rules, likely to take effect next year, were drawn up in response to news that net migration hit a record high of nearly 750,000 last year. They represent a victory for Robert Jenrick, the Immigration Minister who has been pushing for a hardline response to the spike in arrival numbers, despite opposition from other ministers worried about the impact on the health service and the economy.

Mr Cleverly told the House of Commons: 'We will stop immigration undercutting the salary of British workers. We will increase the skilled worker earnings threshold by a third, to GBP 38,700 from next spring in line with the median full-term wage for those kinds of jobs.'

Tory MPs who have been growing increasingly angry at the rise in net migration mostly praised the plan - Ipswich's Tom Hunt said: 'I welcome these measures, I must say it's a shame it's taken so long.' But some accused ministers of not going far enough, with Jacob Rees-Mogg calling for a cap on the overall number of visas granted each year.

Suella Braverman, who was sacked as home secretary last month, said: 'I put forward similar measures six times in the last year. I'm glad that the PM has finally agreed to introducing some of them now but the delay has reduced their impact.'

NHS bosses warned that making it harder for care workers to move to Britain with their families would harm the health sector. Miriam Deakin of NHS Providers described the new rules as 'deeply concerning' and added: 'It's vital that overseas health and care staff continue to view the UK as a viable place to work and live.'

Nicola Ranger of the Royal College of Nursing said: 'Ministers appear comfortable with tearing apart families to score political points. This cruel sanction will deter care workers from coming to the UK, adding to dire workforce shortages in social care and ultimately piling even more pressure on an overburdened NHS.'

Business leaders also expressed concerns. UKHospitality chief executive Kate Nicholls said: 'The Government seems to be running out of answers to fix the UK's long-running labour market shortages. These changes will further shrink the talent pool that the entire economy will be recruiting from, and only worsen the shortages hospitality businesses are facing.'

Alexandra Hall-Chen, principal policy adviser at the Institute of Directors, said: 'Today's announcements will cause concern among businesses already struggling to recruit the labour they need. Continued tightness in the UK labour market is feeding inflation and is a key reason that interest rates remain high.
'Without measures to increase domestic labour supply, policies designed to restrict businesses' ability to hire overseas workers risk worsening inflation and holding down economic growth.'

Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the British Beer and Pub Association, said: 'This will compound the existing shortage of chefs and kitchen staff in hospitality, and hold back sector growth, as the salary increase will make it untenable for many businesses to recruit from overseas alongside the associated costs and complexities that apply alongside this.'

title: Weapons made by US firm Boeing faciliated mass killings in Gaza, says Amnesty
lead: Two attacks on family homes killed 43 civilians including 19 children, with no evidence they were military assets, researchers found
author: Kieron Monks

body.text: Amnesty International is calling for an investigation into potential war crimes over two deadly Israeli airstrikes in Gaza carried out with US bombs.

Two attacks on family homes in the town of Deir al-Balah in central Gaza on 10 October and 22 October killed 43 civilians including 19 children, with no evidence that the properties were used for military purposes, Amnesty researchers found.

The houses belonging to the al-Najjar andAbu Mu'eileq families were located south of Wadi Gaza, in the area to which the Israel Defence Forces (IDF) instructed civilians to flee the heavy bombardment of northern Gaza on 13 October.

'Amnesty's research has found that the airstrikes were either direct attacks on civilians or civilian objects, or indiscriminate attacks, and is calling for them to be investigated as war crimes,' the charity said.
Amnesty said that Israel did not respond to questions over the two incidents. The IDF did not immediately respond to i's request for comment.

Weapons experts identified fragments and serial codes of the bombs as Joint Direct Attack Munitions manufactured by US firm Boeing, one of the most common munitions being used by Israel in its bombardment of Gaza.
Boeing and the US defence department did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Amnesty urged the US to 'follow its own laws and policies regarding the sale of arms', including the Conventional Arms Transfer Policy and Civilian Harm Incident Response Guidance, intended to prevent arms transfers that risk civilian harm.
Agnes Callamard, Amnesty International's secretary general, said that 'US-made weapons facilitated the mass killings of extended families'.

'The fact that US-made munitions are being used by the Israeli military in unlawful attacks with deadly consequences for civilians should be an urgent wake-up call to the Biden administration,' she added.

'To knowingly assist in violations is contrary to the obligation to ensure respect for international humanitarian law. A state that continues to supply arms being used to commit violations may share responsibility for these violations.'

The charity also accused Israel of a 'longstanding pattern of reckless attacks that strike civilian objects' throughout this war and in previous Israeli attacks on Gaza including 2008-9, 2014, and 2021.

More than 15,000 Palestinians and more than 5,000 children have been killed in Gaza since Israel's operations began in the strip following the deadly Hamas raids of 7 October, according to local authorities in the Hamas-governed enclave.
US officials have called on Israel to take greater care to avoid civilian casualties as its invasion of Gaza moves to the densely-populated south.

But asked how the US would respond if Israel did not comply with this request, National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told US news programme Meet The Press on Monday: 'We're going to continue to support Israel as they go after Hamas. The security assistance continues to flow. That's not going to change.'
US State Department official Josh Paul resigned in October over concerns about US arms sales to Israel.

title: Earlier lockdown and disappearing on holiday: Covid inquiry questions for Johnson
lead: The former prime minister will spend more than 10 hours over two days in Lady Hallett's witness stand
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Boris Johnson is expected to face a tough grilling over more than 10 hours from Hugo Keith KC when he appears at the Covid inquiry on Wednesday and Thursday.
Here are 9 questions the former prime minister will have to answer:
Why did you not attend any of the Cobra meetings at the crucial early stage of the covid crisis?

The inquiry has heard how Mr Johnson missed all of the government's emergency committee meetings throughout February 2020, when the virus was taking hold in the UK. Although the scale of the threat was underestimated at the time, the ex-PM has been criticised for not taking personal charge of Cobra until early March. This arguably fed through to a wider lack of decision-making from the centre of government in February.
Why did you go on holiday in February 2020?

Besides Mr Johnson's lack of attendance at Cobra, the inquiry has heard how he took a 10-day holiday in February, around half term, during which he received no papers on the covid emergency. By that stage, there were already several confirmed cases of the virus in the UK and the government's scientists were warning that measures may have to be taken.
Why did you not impose a lockdown earlier?

Witnesses, including Sir Patrick Vallance and Matt Hancock, have conceded that lockdown should have been introduced earlier than 23 March 2020. The former health secretary said it should have been imposed three weeks earlier. Sir Patrick, the former chief scientific adviser, has told the inquiry he personally urged the then prime minister to place London into lockdown around 16 March, because the virus had already taken hold in the capital, but this advice was rejected by Mr Johnson.
What was your role in the policy on care homes?

During his evidence to the inquiry, Mr Hancock was challenged over his statement from the time that the government had thrown a 'protective ring' around care homes, even though it later emerged that elderly patients were discharged from hospitals into these settings without being tested for covid. While the policy seems to have come from the Department of Health and Public Health England, what did Mr Johnson know about this failure?
What did you do to rein in Dominic Cummings?

Several witnesses, including Mr Hancock, have given evidence about the extraordinary power that Mr Cummings, the PM's then chief adviser, held at the heart of government at the height of the crisis. The former health secretary accused Mr Cummings of being a 'malign agent' who contributed to a toxic culture inside Downing St. Mr Cummings in turn has accused Mr Hancock of 'lying' to the inquiry. The nature of his role - and whether this affected the government's covid response - is likely to be a big topic for Mr Johnson to respond to.
Did Carrie Johnson have too much power?

The inquiry has heard claims from some witnesses that Mr Johnson's then fiancee also held sway inside Downing Street. Cabinet Secretary Simon Case sent a WhatsApp joking that Mrs Johnson was the 'real person in charge', while an entry in Sir Patrick's diaries attributed this to Mr Case: 'He says Number 10 is at war with itself. Carrie faction with Gove and another with spads downstairs. The PM is caught in the middle.'
Did you authorise the rewriting of official advice on social distancing?

Sir Patrick has claimed in his diaries that in June 2020, as the government was preparing for a full lifting of restrictions in the UK, No 10 had 'completely rewritten' the scientific advice on the two metre social distancing rule so that it was 'cherry picked' to suggest 'one metre plus' was safe. Sir Patrick also wrote that by then, there was a 'Sage is trouble vibe' appearing in No 10. What role did Mr Johnson play in undermining this scientific advice?
Do you think Eat Out To Help Out was an ill-advised policy?

The inquiry KC is likely to press Mr Johnson on his views of Rishi Sunak's controversial meals discount scheme from August 2020, which scientists have blamed on fuelling a second wave of the virus. Several witnesses, including Mr Hancock and senior scientific advisers, have revealed they were not consulted in advance about the policy. Lady Hallett's inquiry has already heard that in his statement, Mr Johnson said the scheme was 'properly discussed, including with Chris Whitty and Patrick'. But it is not known what Mr Johnson now thinks of the plan itself and whether it contributed to the UK's second wave.
Did you really want to 'let the bodies pile high' and believe the old had had 'a good innings'?

Mr Johnson has denied saying, in autumn 2020, that he wanted to 'let the bodies pile high' rather than impose a second lockdown, but this was confirmed by his former chief of staff, Lord Lister in his witness statement to the inquiry. Sir Patrick's diaries have also claimed that Mr Johnson believed, around the same time, that the elderly had had a 'good innings'. Mr Keith is likely to ask him why he apparently regarded the lives of elderly and other people vulnerable to covid in such a callous manner.

title: Ministers turning a 'blind eye' to problems in the water industry, Labour says
lead: Labour have called for water bosses to face criminal charges and have bonuses blocked
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Ministers have turned a 'blind eye' to problems in the water industry, Labour has claimed, after a firm was accused of misreporting sewage dumping to help it meet environmental targets.

Leaked documents from north-west water company United Utilities suggested that more than 60 cases of pollution were downgraded to the lowest possible level, meaning they were not registered as sewage spills in official records.
According to Informfully Panorama, discharges that can kill wildlife and endanger human health were misreported, allowing United Utilities to increase bills for customers by GBP 5.1m.
Labour's shadow Environment Secretary Steve Reed said the Government had 'wilfully turned a blind eye' to issues in the industry.
He said that, under a Labour Government, any water bosses found to be guilty of lawbreaking would face criminal charges.
' We will give the water regulator powers to block the payment of any bonuses until water bosses have cleaned up their filth,' Mr Reed added.

Under Labour's plans for the water industry, it says it will end self-monitoring and apply a levy on water companies to ensure every water outlet across the country will be fitted with remote monitors to give readings of water cleanliness.

The party says it will also introduce 'severe and automatic' fines for firms that dump sewage into the country's waterways without granting companies the ability to appeal, and will change the laws to make water company bosses criminally liable for excessive sewage spillages.

Labour intends to use a debate in the Commons on Tuesday to bring forward a motion that would extend Ofwat powers to punish companies discharging significant levels of raw sewage in the hope to force the Tories to oppose the plans and leave themselves open to political attacks.
The dire state of the country's rivers and seas is poised to become a key election issue in certain constituencies, with local communities furious over the state of their local rivers and beaches.
The Liberal Democrats are calling for a criminal investigation into the water companies to see whether any laws have been broken.
The party says there are also questions as to why the water companies themselves are reporting incidents rather than the Environmental Agency doing the testing.
Lib Dem Environment Spokesman Tim Farron said: 'It's clear now that only a criminal investigation can punish United Utilities. Both the regulator and government have been proven useless.'
United Utilities denies any wrongdoing.
In a statement, the company said: 'Panorama has made a series of allegations about United Utilities, which we strongly reject.
'Pollution incidents are investigated and action taken where necessary.'

A Defra spokesman said: 'The volume of sewage being discharged into our waters is utterly unacceptable and that's why our Plan for Water is delivering more investment, stronger regulation and tougher enforcement to tackle pollution and clean up our water.'

title: Labour seen as a divided party by voters after Gaza ceasefire row, poll shows
lead: The BMG survey showed that voters disapprove of Keir Starmer's handling of the issue and his overall approval ratings have slipped
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: Labour is now seen as a divided party by voters after Sir Keir Starmer's stance on the Gaza war triggered an internal row, a new poll has revealed.
The Leader of the Opposition has also taken a hit to his ratings with more people disapproving of his performance since the dispute broke out.
While he remains overall significantly more popular than Rishi Sunak, Sir Keir's handling of recent developments in the Israel-Hamas conflict is seen by the public as worse than the Prime Minister's.

Eight Labour shadow ministers resigned from the front bench after being ordered not to vote in support of a permanent ceasefire in Gaza, with dozens of councillors leaving the party in protest at the leader's support of Israel's right to retaliate after the 7 October terror attacks by Hamas.

A BMG Research poll for Informfully conducted last week found that 24 per cent of the public think Sir Keir has responded well to the conflict, with 39 per cent saying his handling of it has been bad. Even among Labour voters views are evenly split, with 37 per cent on each side.
Mr Sunak's response is viewed less negatively, with 33 per cent in favour and 38 per cent opposed.

Voters are now more likely to see Labour as a divided party than a united one: 38 per cent said it was united and 43 per cent disagreed, a significant turnaround from October when the figures were 48 and 28 per cent respectively.
But the Conservatives are still seen as more sharply divided than the Opposition, with 62 per cent saying the Tories are split in the wake of public fights over immigration and tax policy.

Sir Keir's overall satisfaction figures stand at -6 on balance, much better than the Prime Minister's rating of -33. But BMG's finding that 35 per cent of voters are dissatisfied with the Leader of the Opposition is the highest in over a year.
He has taken a more assertive line on Israel since the end of the week-long pause in fighting, warning the country not to resume its all-out assault on Gaza.

Speaking in Dubai, where he met regional leaders during the COP 28 climate summit, Sir Keir said: 'Too many innocent Palestinian lives, particularly children, have already been lost in this conflict, and it is imperative that if there are any further hostilities, it can't simply be a return to where we were before this cessation of hostilities.'

title: Follow the trail of business-class carbon emissions to COP28
lead: However imaginative the fudges and partial fixes, the transition to net zero needs to happen faster
author: Anne McElvoy

body.text: COP climate summits are the oddest fixture among the annual roster of 'global moments', a feast of good intentions in the worst year on record for planetary warming - with wildfires, droughts, extreme spikes in heat and erratic weather events reminding us that the planet is in climate trouble.

Industrialised countries know to switch their energy mix and support poorer ones in lessening dependency on fossil fuels. At the same time, geopolitics makes governments nervous about taking risks on tried and trusted energy supplies, slow to ditch fossil fuels, and in the case of Britain, pursue a zig-zag of committing to net zero targets, which turn out to be stretchy when the political pressure mounts. Rishi Sunak spent a mere 11 hours at COP28, which tells us that he does not deem this a popularity-boosting event in the election. In contrast, Sir Keir Starmer stayed all weekend.

Overall, the Dubai gathering comes wreathed in a trail of business-class carbon emissions, as the veteran US climate envoy John Kerry rubs shoulders with King Charles III. And neither can you move in the glitzy Expo centre or five-star hotel receptions for bankers and finance folk. The richer you are these days, the more likely you will be at the UN climate summit: Michael Bloomberg and Bill Gates mingle with BlackRock's Larry Fink and herds of major-league chief executives. We might ask why so many people who command resource and power climate-friendly decisions feel they need to gather in a vast shoal of performative power, rather than simply delivering more intently on the aims of the last session held in Sharm-el-Sheikh or indeed Glasgow the year before.

But the central defence of the jamboree is that it keeps noses to the climate grindstone, in terms of pushing for more renewable resources (where the UK has a decent record of investment) - and pushes climate change on a global agenda clouded by the impact of the war in Ukraine and ensuing pivots in energy dependency. These days, it also brings together in the Gulf many leaders who will be having anxious sidebar conversations about the wider economic and social effects of the violence in Israel and Gaza.

Some of the glaring COP28 contradictions are, however, worth paying attention to, not least because a lot of effort and communications advice goes into persuading us not asking hard questions. The UAE is host to a 70,000-strong meeting and can afford to be so, not least because it the seventh-largest producer of oil worldwide, with plans for expansion of this business. It is a major evasion (to put it politely) for Dr Sultan Al Jaber - the UAE host of COP and head of the state oil company - to claim that there is 'no science' behind the demand to phase out fossil fuels in order to meet the Paris Agreement target to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. There most certainly is, unless anyone has a better idea. Which they have not.

The mirror-world of Emirates communication is a study in what is missed out of the barrage of self-advertising, and glossy images of Dubai as a Xanadu of prosperity and opportunity (which treads lightly on its autocratic governance). So this week, delegates will be relentlessly informed about the Emirates' very sizeable investment in renewable energy and green transitions, which deserves some acknowledgement.
