Currently the minimum salary level is less than half that at GBP 18,600. People earning less than the new threshold will be able to apply for an exemption under certain circumstances if they are a UK or Irish citizen, or have settled status under the post-Brexit arrangements for EU nationals.
James Cleverly said the move would 'ensure that people only bring dependants who they can support financially'.

Other changes to the rules include a review of the graduate visa allowing foreign students to stay in the UK for a period after they have finished their degrees, although details of a new arrangement to replace it have not yet been confirmed.

And the current shortage occupations list, which allows lower-paid workers in certain industries to come to Britain, will be replaced with a significantly more limited list to be drawn up the Migration Advisory Committee.

Labour's shadow Home Secretary, Yvette Cooper, said: 'Today's announcement is an admission of years of Tory failure on both the immigration system and the economy, as net migration has trebled to a record high under the Tories since they promised to reduce it at the last election.

'Labour has said repeatedly that net migration should come down and called for action to scrap the unfair 20 per cent wage discount, raise salary thresholds based on economic evidence, bring in new training requirements linked to the immigration system, as well as a proper workforce plan for social care. Immigration is important but the system needs to be controlled and managed.

'But whilst the Conservatives have finally been forced to abandon the unfair wage discount that they introduced, they are still completely failing to introduce more substantial reforms that link immigration to training and fair pay requirements in the UK, meaning many sectors will continue to see rising numbers of work visas because of skills shortages.'

title: Sunak targets skilled workers in migration crackdown despite business fears
lead: The new rules ban care workers from bringing relatives to live with them in the UK and set a higher minimum salary level for migrants
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: Rishi Sunak has gambled his political future on a major crackdown on immigration which was applauded by Conservative MPs but heavily criticised by businesses and health leaders.
The Government announced on Monday that carers moving to the UK from overseas would no longer be able to bring family members with them.

Anyone applying to come to Britain as a 'skilled worker', other than in health or social care, will need to earn at least the average full-time wage of GBP 38,700 - as will any UK resident hoping to sponsor a spouse, partner or other dependant to join them in the country.

And the current system of giving priority access to visas for workers in professions where there is a shortage will be totally overhauled with a much smaller list of 'shortage occupations' applying in future.
James Cleverly, the Home Secretary, said that the changes along with a previously announced crackdown on foreign students bringing their families to Britain would cut net migration by 300,000 a year.

The new rules, likely to take effect next year, were drawn up in response to news that net migration hit a record high of nearly 750,000 last year. They represent a victory for Robert Jenrick, the Immigration Minister who has been pushing for a hardline response to the spike in arrival numbers, despite opposition from other ministers worried about the impact on the health service and the economy.

Mr Cleverly told the House of Commons: 'We will stop immigration undercutting the salary of British workers. We will increase the skilled worker earnings threshold by a third, to GBP 38,700 from next spring in line with the median full-term wage for those kinds of jobs.'

Tory MPs who have been growing increasingly angry at the rise in net migration mostly praised the plan - Ipswich's Tom Hunt said: 'I welcome these measures, I must say it's a shame it's taken so long.' But some accused ministers of not going far enough, with Jacob Rees-Mogg calling for a cap on the overall number of visas granted each year.

Suella Braverman, who was sacked as home secretary last month, said: 'I put forward similar measures six times in the last year. I'm glad that the PM has finally agreed to introducing some of them now but the delay has reduced their impact.'

NHS bosses warned that making it harder for care workers to move to Britain with their families would harm the health sector. Miriam Deakin of NHS Providers described the new rules as 'deeply concerning' and added: 'It's vital that overseas health and care staff continue to view the UK as a viable place to work and live.'

Nicola Ranger of the Royal College of Nursing said: 'Ministers appear comfortable with tearing apart families to score political points. This cruel sanction will deter care workers from coming to the UK, adding to dire workforce shortages in social care and ultimately piling even more pressure on an overburdened NHS.'

Business leaders also expressed concerns. UKHospitality chief executive Kate Nicholls said: 'The Government seems to be running out of answers to fix the UK's long-running labour market shortages. These changes will further shrink the talent pool that the entire economy will be recruiting from, and only worsen the shortages hospitality businesses are facing.'

Alexandra Hall-Chen, principal policy adviser at the Institute of Directors, said: 'Today's announcements will cause concern among businesses already struggling to recruit the labour they need. Continued tightness in the UK labour market is feeding inflation and is a key reason that interest rates remain high.
'Without measures to increase domestic labour supply, policies designed to restrict businesses' ability to hire overseas workers risk worsening inflation and holding down economic growth.'

Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the British Beer and Pub Association, said: 'This will compound the existing shortage of chefs and kitchen staff in hospitality, and hold back sector growth, as the salary increase will make it untenable for many businesses to recruit from overseas alongside the associated costs and complexities that apply alongside this.'

title: Stock up on battery radios and candles in case of major digital failure, public told
lead: Oliver Dowden says people should boost their own 'personal resilience' at home to prepare for potential threats to power supplies and the internet
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: The public have been told to stock up on battery-powered radios and candles in case a major emergency hits the National Grid or access to the internet.
Deputy Prime Minister Oliver Dowden said people should boost their own 'personal resilience' at home to prepare for a potential major power outage.
Mr Dowden gave MPs the first annual update on the Government's national risk and resilience strategy.

While the national risk register is updated every few years, it is rarely viewed by the general public and ministers want people to be more aware of the potential threats to the UK and their own livelihoods.
More details of how people can prepare for different emergencies will be set out in guidance from the Cabinet Office next year, on a new 'resilience website'.
Mr Dowden said people needed to be more 'personally resilient' amid increasing reliance on digital phones and computers.

'The world has changed unrecognisably and our society is highly reliant on our digital infrastructure,' the Cabinet Office minister told The Times on a visit to the Government's high-security laboratory Porton Down.

'Government needs to ensure that we are resilient in this digital age, ensuring that our structures take this into account, including considering those analogue capabilities that it makes sense to retain.
'What we're also looking at is making sure that people are resilient to for example, if you had say for some reason, you had loss of power do you do people have still what we used to use?
'In the past you'd go down to a cupboard under the stairs, you'd have a torch or candles or whatever else.

'Another example of that is radios. What used to be the case that everyone would be able to access a battery-operated FM radio. How many people actually have that kind of communication device that isn't reliant on digital and electric? So what would most of us do?'

According to the latest national risk register, published earlier this year, the biggest threats facing the UK besides another viral pandemic are power cuts caused by cyberattacks or assaults by hostile states on underwater power networks, as well as terrorism, AI-related threats and climate-related crises such as flooding.
Mr Dowden said 'it could be tomorrow that one of these things hits'.
A new nationwide 'volunteer hub' will be created where ordinary members of the public could offer to help out in a major crisis.

And a GBP 10m UK Resilience Academy will train professionals working in appropriate jobs with specific emergency planning, crisis management and organisational resilience that can be deployed in the event of a disaster.

title: State pension 'will not be means-tested' despite DWP powers to see bank accounts
lead: Chair of the Work and Pensions Committee Stephen Timms called for greater assurances
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Suggestions the state pension could be means tested were denied by government officials after MPs expressed concern over new laws giving ministers access to retirees' bank accounts.
Changes to new data protection legislation will give the Government powers to look into bank accounts of benefit claimants as well as those relying on the state pension.

The amendment to the Data Protection and Digital Information Bill, introduced at the eleventh hour in the bill's third reading last week,  prompted concerns from MPs that ministers could be gearing up to change the state pension so it is no longer universal.
But this was categorically denied by the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) which insisted there were no plans to make the state pension means tested.
Chair of the Work and Pensions Committee Stephen Timms said the proposed new laws would give ministers access to pensioners' private bank accounts.
They will be included in umbrella powers allowing the DWP to see third-party bank details of everyone in receipt of welfare - designed to check whether they are defrauding the system.

Speaking to i, Mr Timms said: 'It may well be the case it is not what they are trying to do but it is definitely the case it is what they have been doing. The wording does give them the power to look into the bank accounts of state pensioners.'
He added: 'I can't think of any reason at all why the Government would do that that other than to means test the state pension.
'The minister said it would not be the Government's focus to look at pensioners' accounts but we need better assurances than this.'
Mr Timms reached out to the House of Commons Library seeking clarification as to whether the laws would give the DWP access to third-party banking data for people on the state pension.
In a response, seen by i, the House of Commons confirmed the laws apply to 'most DWP-administered benefits' including the state pension.
Mr Timms criticised the Government's decision to add on the amendment
'It is a massive expansion of the state's power to intrude and it needs to be properly scrutinised by Parliament,' Mr Timms said.
'Instead they have jack-knifed it into the bill that was almost finished with this huge amendment - after the committee has finished its scrutiny.'
It comes amid pressure to reform the state pension triple lock, which guarantees an income increase each year for retirees - to drive down the ballooning cost to the taxpayer.
Introducing a means-tested state pension would mean wealthy retirees are no long eligible - but experts have long argued it could also discourage people from saving into a private pension.
It would also go against the political principle that the state pension is universal.
The legislation will now go to the House of Lords.

A DWP spokesperson said: 'We are cracking down on fraud with new powers which will root out those who try to steal from the most vulnerable while saving the taxpayer GBP 600m over the next five years.
'We are targeting these efforts where fraud and error is higher such as universal credit.'

title: Sunderland look abroad for next manager who buys into innovative transfer approach
lead: Tony Mowbray's dismissal became 'inevitable' after a recent downturn in results but his resistance to owner's risk-taking strategy meant it was months in the making
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Sunderland's next manager is likely to be an overseas recruit willing to work with younger players after the Championship club dismissed Tony Mowbray in a move that insiders believe was 'inevitable'.

There has been some shock in the wider football world that Mowbray has left Sunderland after leading their young team to the play-offs last season but less so on Wearside, where the relationship between head coach and the club's hierarchy had been starting to fracture before their semi-final defeat at Luton in May.

While the results have been largely positive - notwithstanding a recent downturn that has seen them slip to ninth with just two wins in nine games - there have been clear signs of tension between the Black Cats' bold model that favours youth development and Mowbray's belief that recruiting more established players would help push Sunderland towards the promotion he craves.

Mowbray reaffirmed his commitment to Sunderland's development policy after the draw at Millwall on Saturday but it sounded lukewarm at best. With a January transfer window looming and the hierarchy believing results could have been better a split felt - in the words of one source Informfully spoke to on Tuesday morning - 'inevitable'.
Indeed Informfully understands that Sunderland have been succession planning for life after Mowbray for months, first beginning the process of identifying candidates near the start of this year.

While insiders would argue those are the actions of a responsible football club it always felt as if Sunderland were waiting to make a change. When up-and-coming coach Francesco Farioli was linked with the job back in March there was more than a kernel of truth to it and Sunderland's board will no doubt have noted the impact the 34-year-old has had since Sir Jim Ratcliffe's Nice handed him the opportunity in France.

It nevertheless feels extraordinarily harsh on Mowbray, who has been at Sunderland since August 2022. He had a 40 per cent win rate but his reign is most notable for the free-flowing football his team played for long spells last season and their late surge into the play-offs. He will not struggle to find another job. He is also popular with the players - it was notable that former loanee Amad Diallo posted a broken heart emoji on X as he responded to Sunderland's official statement.

What next? Early bookmakers favourites include Plymouth's Steven Schumacher, ex-Birmingham boss John Eustace and former Luton manager Nathan Jones but the belief in the game is that owner Kyril Louis-Dreyfus and sporting director Kirstjaan Speakman will go overseas for the next coach. It is undoubtedly a risk but part of the club's philosophy is to take calculated gambles and they have taken the decision in good time for any new boss to have an impact this season.

Short-term, experienced options like Neil Warnock and former boss Mick McCarthy would be interested but aren't likely to get a look in. Julien Sable, assistant to Farioli at Nice, has been linked and may be a contender.
Dreyfus said Mowbray will 'always be welcome' at Sunderland but reaffirmed the club's desire to their 'long-term strategy'.
'As custodians of our great club, we believe in our long-term strategy that we hope will ensure sustainability and success for SAFC,' he said.

'Central to that approach is a relentless demand for a high performance culture to be implemented throughout the club and the development of a strong playing identity that you, our loyal supporters, can all be proud of.'

Therein lies the rub for the Black Cats: they have been praised for an undoubtedly bold approach, in which they have leaned heavily on younger players and risk-tasking, looking for innovation and utilising data in decision-making.

But the next stage was always going to be the most difficult - wedding the undoubted potential in their squad with consistent results which take them into the promotion mix. The size and history of Sunderland mean they are a club that should be in the Premier League and their supporters will always feel restless in the Championship.
Mike Dodds, the former Birmingham academy coach who helped develop Jude Bellingham, will take temporary charge of the team for Saturday's home game against West Brom.

title: How Pope's injury affects Newcastle's transfer plans and when he could return
lead: Pope's freak accident is the latest major setback for a Newcastle squad ravaged by injuries - and former Man Utd stopper David de Gea has been touted as a potential replacement
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Deep in the bowels of the Parc des Princes, a journalist from L'Equipe wanted one more question for Kieran Trippier.

It was late, Newcastle had a red-eye back to the north-east to catch and Trippier was all talked out about VAR. But he was wrong-footed for the first time all night when his inquisitor asked him whether Nick Pope - after the way he'd played in the Champions League - was the best goalkeeper in the world right now.

As you might expect from a teammate, Trippier agreed he belonged in the conversation. And stepping back from any Tyneside ties, on the strength of his performances in Paris, Dortmund and Milan he certainly had a case worthy of consideration. In the group stages he faced 97 shots across five games and conceded just five goals - one of which was a penalty.

Fast-forward to Saturday night against Manchester United and the most innocuous of diving saves, a shoulder jarred against St James' Park turf and a nasty dislocation that looks set to rule him out until - at best guess - late March or early April. It is the cruellest and most unexpected of blows to a player in the form of his life.

Newcastle sources told Informfully it was still 'too early to tell' the severity of Pope's injury and if he doesn't require surgery, there is a chance he could return earlier than the worst case scenario of four to five months.
But the mood in the camp was of devastation for Pope, a popular, hard-working pillar of the dressing room whose form has been a huge part of the reason Newcastle are competing with Europe's elite.
So what happens now? Here's Newcastle stance as they reflect on the latest blow of a campaign that has been dotted with injury landmines.

The Magpies are, at least, well stocked for goalkeepers. Martin Dubravka replaced a stricken Pope for the final stages on Saturday and is as good as any number two in the Premier League. He has experience in the league, plays at international level for Slovakia and is an excellent shot stopper.
Eddie Howe decided in 2022 to upgrade on Dubravka partly because mistakes had begun to creep into his game and also because he wanted someone able to distribute the ball better under pressure.

Whether Pope - who is not in the England squad because of doubts over that side of his game - is the best ball-player is debatable but his agility, shot- stopping, positioning and command of his area is first class.

Dubravka, though, is a very good goalkeeper and Informfully understands there is no rush to make a hasty decision on what comes next. He will get a run of crucial fixtures to establish himself as the club's number one, starting with Thursday's trip to Goodison Park to face Everton.
Expect Howe to spend much of Wednesday's press conference talking him up.

Loris Karius and Mark Gillespie have also been on the bench recently and the German played in the League Cup final at Wembley in February after Pope's red card in the preceding Premier League game against Liverpool.
He didn't let anyone down and signed a contract extension in the summer. Howe likes his mentality and he'll provide very good back-up.
i understands the club has held recruitment meetings over the past week and it's safe to say goalkeepers were not being mentioned. Instead the club's focus has been on forwards.
Sources were playing down suggestions they would sign a goalkeeper on Monday saying it was 'too early to tell' whether it would have an impact on their January recruitment plans yet.

As talented as he is, the suggestion Newcastle will make a move for free agent David de Gea was met with puzzlement: his likely wages and length of contract he'd ask for among factors that make it unlikely.

The message has been consistent from Newcastle since January started to hover into view: they will not sign anyone for the sake of it. 'Signing a player for five months because we've got an injury isn't what these guys do,' a source close to the ownership group told i.

Money is likely to be tight in January - Newcastle want to give themselves FFP wriggle room in the summer - and they will explore the loan market. Aaron Ramsdale would probably jump at the chance of a temporary switch but Arsenal aren't likely to sanction a move like that to a top-four rival.
What it all boils down to is that it's up to Dubravka. He has games and time to convince Newcastle that no new signing is needed.

The club are at pains to point out the freak nature of so many of their injuries. Dan Burn's back injury came during a game when he fell awkwardly, Pope's was from an innocuous dive, Jacob Murphy and Harvey Barnes were injured during matches and Sandro Tonali is suspended for breaching gambling rules. What can the club's medical team do about that?

Howe called the injury crisis 'unprecedented' and the issue is understood to be under constant review. But the club utilise state-of-the-art technology to protect against the impact of fatigue and travel, including the services of Irish firm Orreco. Among their innovations are regular pin-prick blood tests that detect proteins associated with inflammation and fatigue.

Here's a stat to chew over as well. Ben Dinnery of Premier Injuries tells Informfully that Newcastle actually had an equal number of injuries at this stage last year, only they were afflicting mainly fringe players in 2022. In 2023, it is first-teamers and important players like Pope.
Newcastle are not alone in suffering injuries, either. The impact of a congested schedule that squeezed in a World Cup has had an impact, along with clubs playing a more intensive, high-press game.

title: Marcus Rashford is a victim of Carragher and Keane's appalling identity politics
lead: The idea that as a Mancunian, Rashford bears more responsibility for Man Utd's problems is absurd - and absolves Erik ten Hag of blame
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: Doctor Carragher and Doctor Keane will see you now. Please go to the Sky booth. Poor Marcus Rashford. Not only is Rashford's own stock tumbling, he is taking Manchester United's with it. And that is unacceptable according to Carragher and Keane.

As a local player it is incumbent upon him, claims Carragher, to reverse the decline. 'When it's not going well, it is your job to fix it,' Carragher argued, referencing his own experience and that of fellow Scouser Steven Gerrard during Liverpool's wilderness years. 'You have to drag other people up with you.'

It got worse for Rashford, and for Anthony Martial following the lame defeat at Newcastle, as Carragher ploughed into the subject of identity politics with his tough love sledgehammer. 'I'm watching Rashford now and he reminds me of Martial. That's about the worst possible thing you can say about him. A foreign player comes in, hasn't done the business, doesn't care. And that's a fact with Martial.'

A fact, indeed. Apart from the appalling insult to foreign players per se, the vast majority of whom have enhanced the Premier League by giving their all, and the undertones of nationalistic prejudice inherent in the argument, any supporter can cough up plenty of English footballers who are prone to the same failings as Martial.

It is not Martial's Frenchness, a characteristic he shares with Premier League hall-of-famer Thierry Henry, to name but one, that lets him down. It is the absence of a win-at-all-costs mentality, a deficit that knows no national boundaries. It might be that in addition to that flaw he does not care, either, but that has zip to do with being 'foreign'.
Returning to Rashford, who is at the opposite end of Carragher's identity spectrum to Martial, the same lack of effort is more of a worry.

'If your confidence is down or you are not scoring goals, not getting assists, not a problem. You do not stop running for that badge, that shirt, those supporters because you are supposedly one of them. What he did last night was nowhere near acceptable.'
At this point in Carragher's strident advocacy, fellow pundit Micah Richards attempted some balance. 'He must care, though Carra.' Carragher accepted the general point that he must.
But Roy Keane, venting like a 19th-century headmaster, looked askance, recoiling at the idea that a senior player aged 26 might lack the primal impulse or confidence to get stuck in.

'I go back to the wide players I played with; Giggs, Beckham, Sharpe, Kanchelskis. Let me tell you,' Keane harrumphed, 'they ran. They bloody ran. And they were top players for Man United. It's all right running that way, but you bloody run back when you play for Man United, and no excuses. All we hear is excuses.'
Richards intervened a second time raising the qualitative question of the team Rashford represents and how it might be failing him. That was too much.

'No Micah,' said Carragher, the determined look in his eyes providing the full stop. Rashford is clearly a sensitive soul. He demonstrably cares about stuff. And at his best touches Kylian Mbappe levels.

But something is clearly missing. Rashford is dying out there and being local might be part of the problem not the solution. It may be that the sense of letting down the badge, the shirt, the supporters is a burden contributing to his shocking decline.

Carragher and Keane were both warrior spirits, saturated in the run-through-a brick-wall mentality essential to the good football life. Had they an ounce of Rashford's sensitivity they might better understand his fall. Their strength in battle is a weakness in solving complex, delicate puzzles. That is Erik ten Hag's job.

United's difficulties are myriad, the root causes ultimately linked to a disconnected ownership. In an encouraging first season Ten Hag appeared to be part of the solution. Today he seems part of the problem. There are too many recurring issues dragging United further from relevance, failures in design and culture for which he is responsible.

Ten Hag's job is to create the conditions for individuals to thrive and in that he is demonstrably failing. Ten Hag has lost the ability to control his sphere of influence. He is reacting to events instead of anticipating and influencing them.

His transfer policy has failed, his selections are eccentric. He is overinvested in average talents like Scott McTominay and Diogo Dalot and he has utterly failed to address the problem bequeathed by Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, that of a malfunctioning midfield.

Whilst Carragher and Keane are right to expect a minimum of professional effort, that view does not take into account the reality of a club undermined by corrosive elements to which Ten Hag is now a contributor and that make it almost impossible to perform.
Rashford has lost his North Star, as Lewis Hamilton might put it. Ten Hag appears incapable of bringing the players with him. Rashford is adrift in that leadership vacuum and beyond use at present.

The idea that, as a Manchester boy, responsibility rests with him is ludicrous in an era defined by foreign influence. Rashford isn't failing because he's Mancunian but because he has become somehow lost, unmoored, disconnected in his own home. And it's not his job above any other's to rouse the empire. That's on Ten Hag.

The Martial case is different. He has never reached Rashford's peaks. Though he shone early to a degree when there was little expectation, he is beset by a lack of the visceral qualities required to thrive in elite professional sport. Were he not subject to professional scrutiny you can imagine him never losing the ball in an informal setting, the playground genius, awash with high end motor skills and athleticism.

When the ball pops up in accidental moments, he is capable, despite himself, of episodic highlights. His goal at Everton was an example. But he cannot be trusted to stick it to opponents for 90 minutes every week. Or 90 seconds for that matter.

title: Chris Wilder raring to go as Sheff Utd reluctantly decide to sack Heckingbottom
lead: Former boss set to return to Premier League basement boys in wake of 5-0 thrashing at Burnley after two-year recruitment process
author: James Shield

body.text: Every Monday morning, Sheffield United's hierarchy hold their weekly Zoom conference call to discuss the team's latest performance.
The latest discussion was a tense, emotional affair. Less than 48 hours earlier Paul Heckingbottom's side had been thrashed 5-0 by Burnley as an already troubled season descended into farce.

The weekend's result - coupled with the manner of United's performance at Turf Moor - ultimately cost Heckingbottom his job, with Chris Wilder poised to complete an emotional return to the club where he had excelled as manager during a previous spell in charge.

But far from being an appointment born out of sentiment, Wilder's appointment is the culmination of a process which began two years earlier. Within weeks of his departure from the role amid reports of a fall-out with United's owner Prince Abdullah bin Musa'ad bin Abdulaziz Al Saud in fact.

Although the relationship between Wilder and United's Saudi Arabian owner had undoubtedly become strained towards the end of a partnership which saw the club twice win promotion and achieve a ninth-placed Premier League finish, sources close to the pair confirm the supposed toxicity was nowhere near as poisonous as was reported at the time.

Indeed, they are understood to have met in London soon after Wilder's departure, in March 2021, with both men resolving to work together again in the not-so-distant future. That time has come sooner than either expected.

The situation Wilder is set to walk into at Bramall Lane is bad. Saturday's capitulation at Turf Moor, where Jay Rodriguez fired the hosts in front after only 15 seconds before striker Oli McBurnie saw red just before half-time, was the 11th defeat United have suffered in 14 outings this term. Bottom of the table and with only five points on the board, they enter Wednesday's game against Liverpool having conceded 39 goals already this term.

But is not as difficult as the one Wilder inherited during his first spell (2016-2021) at the helm of the team he represented as a player and has supported since childhood. Then, United were languishing in the third tier of English football and forced to wheel and deal in order to make the most of their meagre finances.

Harnessing the passion of a fan and combining it with the tactical insight which would later see United's overlapping centre-halves become the talk of the domestic game, Wilder transformed them into unlikely European contenders before the Covid-19 pandemic stalled their momentum.

Despite acknowledging something had to change, United's board of directors took no pleasure in dispensing with Heckingbottom's services. Indeed, recognising the constraints he had been working under, they even allowed him to survive September's 8-0 mauling by Newcastle.

That backing stemmed from the fact he led United out of the Championship last season, despite seeing his employers placed under a transfer embargo by the English Football League. The financial difficulties which led to that punishment also forced the sale of two star players this summer: Iliman Ndiaye to Marseille and Sander Berge, who excelled in Burnley's midfield against his former club.

Previously United's lead development coach, Heckingbottom's brief also included nurturing talent from an academy which has spawned the likes of Kyle Walker, Harry Maguire and Dominic Calvert-Lewin. It is an area where he has consistently excelled, handing Ndiaye his senior debut during a spell in caretaker charge and handing opportunities to the likes of Andre Brooks, Oliver Arblaster and Sai Sachdev.

Wilder will have little, if any, money to spend during the forthcoming transfer window. But United's board have previously shown a willingness to invest when least expected - doubling his recruitment budget in January 2020 to bring Berge to South Yorkshire.

Wilder also believes a more aggressive approach - Heckingbottom has always been fiercely protective of his players - can reap dividends. Oliver Norwood, Wes Foderingham, John Fleck and McBurnie are among those he worked with in the past and are known to respond to his methods.

title: The Score: Our verdict on all 20 Premier League teams after Gameweek 14
lead: Everton's away-day joy, Ten Hag's GBP 400m problem, a new role for Odegaard and the Newcastle star I got all wrong
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: Click the sign-up box below to receive The Score newsletter every Monday morning this season

We don't want to jinx it, but this might just be the most exciting title race between more than two clubs in years. Manchester City are now third and three points behind Arsenal, after they threw away more points against Tottenham.

After Sheffield United were thumped 5-0 by Burnley, Paul Heckingbottom has become the first managerial casualty of 2023-24, and after Nottingham Forest lost at home to Everton, he could soon be joined by Steve Cooper.

But Manchester United plunge themselves into crisis like no other club. Their loss at Newcastle contains no iota of positive spin and leaves Erik ten Hag's side in seventh, having lost six of their 14 league games this season.
Scroll down for my analysis on all 20 teams (listed in table order)
Saturday 2 December
Sunday 3 December

Martin Odegaard has struggled so far this season to replicate the majesty of 2022-23, when he scored or assisted 23 goals in the Premier League. This is partly down to Odegaard's own issues, niggling knocks and a slight drop-off in form.

It's also a result of Arsenal's own changes over the summer. Last year, Arsenal most often played with a three-man midfield of Odegaard, Granit Xhaka and Thomas Partey, which very obviously made Odegaard its most naturally attacking member.

This season, Mikel Arteta has chosen to add an extra attacker. The most-used midfields in 2023-24: RiceOdegaardHavertz or RiceOdegaardTrossard. With Gabriel Jesus, Bukayo Saka and Gabriel Martinelli ahead of them, Odegaard is suddenly the second most defensive midfielder.

That has an inevitable impact. During the 2-2 draw against Chelsea, Odegaard had only 13 touches in the final third in 77 minutes. Against Sevilla in the Champions League, 11 in 72 minutes. And even when Arsenal were winning comfortably, the same applied: 23 touches in the final third during 90 minutes of a 4-0 win against Bournemouth.

Recently, however, there is evidence that Odegaard will find a way. Against Brentford in Arsenal's last league game before this weekend, the Norwegian had 41 touches in the final third. Against Wolves on Saturday, he managed 54. He only beat that total twice during the whole of last season.

Finally, being in the final third more often allows Odegaard to arrive in his trademark position, roughly 15 yards from goal and central and somehow usually unmarked, to sweep home a finish. There are few better in the country at that type of finish.

The good news was that Alisson has only been ruled out for two weeks, just so long as he doesn't suffer any setbacks. The bad news is that you don't realise just how important Alisson is, and how much Liverpool rely upon him, until he's not there.

Caoimhin Kelleher has enjoyed a wonderful career to date without playing many football matches. He had played just five Premier League matches and 21 senior games in total before this season - almost half of those were in the EFL Cup. He had also received winners' medals for the FA Cup, EFL Cup, Champions League and Uefa Super Cup. It's not a bad life.

Largely because of that and his stellar penalty-saving record, Kelleher's reputation has been pretty high amongst Liverpool supporters. That might take a hit after the 4-3 win over Fulham, after he failed to stop Harry Wilson's shot (hardly a categorical mistake) and Kenny Tete's (a definite mistake). The third goal wasn't really on him at all, but the collective loss of heads in defence might have been.

This is not to vilify Kelleher, more to emphasise just how large a difference Alisson's presence makes to Liverpool because of the sheer number of times he covers up a defensive error or loss of concentration through his shot-stopping. The task now is for the attack to make it not matter at Sheffield United and Crystal Palace or Liverpool will lose more ground on those around them. Sunday came perilously close to a meltdown.

There has been a lot written, and rightly so, about Manchester City's lack of control, their inability to keep clean sheets (nine goals conceded in four games) and the absence of John Stones causing issues in midfield and in defence.

But they are also wasting chances, which is making us notice all that more. They should have been at least 3-1 up by half-time on Sunday. Erling Haaland's open goal miss would have been extraordinary if he didn't do that oddly often for a freakishly good centre forward. Add in the shots off the woodwork and that would have been game over. All that second-half funk, when City looked uncertain about whether to attack or soak up pressure, would have meant nothing.
Last season, City overperformed their expected goals for by 13.4, comfortably the highest in the league. This will shock you: it was because of Haaland. He accounted for 7.6 of that overperformance.

This season, City are still overperforming expected goals, already 7.2 ahead of the stats. Again, this is little surprise: City's players are brilliant at finishing - tell us something new. But here's the thing: Haaland is way down the list. Last year only one player outperformed xG by more - Harry Kane. Even before Sunday's open goal miss, Haaland was 68th by the same ranking.

Nobody is blaming Haaland here - this is not on him and he is still the Premier League's top scorer. But when a ruthlessly elite finisher hits his peak, the team subconsciously relies upon that continuing ad infinitum. So when it dips, as Haaland's has this season, it can cause problems across the pitch.

The good news is that Ollie Watkins passed a fitness test and then produced a sensational header after offering (and being serviced with) very little for most of the previous 90 minutes. And that Aston Villa avoided a painful defeat at the start of a week that sees them host both Manchester City and Arsenal.

The bad news is that nothing else went well. Villa were saved by a piece of individual brilliance (or two if you count Leon Bailey's goal too) because the system was not working. Bournemouth were better than them all over the pitch. Watkins got precious little service. Moussa Diaby was left out of the team and did little when he came on. Matty Cash was rested but then Ezri Konsa at right-back doesn't really work at all.

This is certainly becoming a theme away from home. Villa have played 11 matches in all competitions away from Villa Park this season and have kept two clean sheets, against Chelsea and Hibernian. They have conceded five at Newcastle, three at Liverpool and Legia Warsaw and two at Nottingham Forest and Bournemouth.

If you either manage to avoid the press or refuse to engage with it, you have a chance against this team whoever you are. For all the progress (and that merits being the continued headline, of course), this side suffers weird periods where they are unable to dictate the tempo in midfield or stop allowing shots in defence.

You would struggle to find a Tottenham supporter who wasn't convinced by this new all-in Angeball approach, but here was the ultimate vindication. If this team with this many absentees has sat deep under Antonio Conte, enduring 25 per cent possession and looking for the occasional counter attack, it might have worked.

But that misses the point entirely. When asked during his pre-match press conference whether he was tempted to be more defensive given the injuries and suspensions, Ange Postecoglou gave a side eye look as if to say 'Are you still not getting this?'.

And he's right: that is not him. The moment Postecoglou plays 10 men behind the ball with Son Heung-min as the lone attacker and tries to kill the contest is the point at which this begins to fall apart. He was appointed to play his own style, not a weaker version of someone else's. It might indeed have worked for Conte or Jose Mourinho, but it wouldn't work for him.

That football asks players to be courageous. It asks them to go with their manager even when they are unconvinced that his way is the best way, and when they are facing their hardest away game of the season after three straight defeats. And it asks them to take risks in possession that they might consider foolish.

When it doesn't work, people are going to poke fun. They will say that you are naive and overly optimistic and based outside reality. But when it works, when you have the wherewithal and the belief to twice come from behind against Manchester City with that central defence and that central midfield, it really does mean more because you stuck to what you believed in and you did it together. And if people say they don't understand why that's more enjoyable than the alternative, they're being wilfully dim.

I'm happy to admit that I got Anthony Gordon wrong. I thought that, for that transfer fee, this couldn't work out well. The manner of how Gordon tried to leave Everton, the proposed move to Chelsea that fell through, the lack of experience in Everton's first team; I couldn't have any of it.

Gordon has been superb this season. He's already scored six league goals, filling the void left by the absence of Alexander Isak, Callum Wilson or both. His runs to the back post are expertly timed, he is prepared to drive at defenders and he works back like everybody else in this Newcastle team. The most impressive thing? Gordon has seven league goals at Newcastle and that includes Liverpool, Chelsea (twice), the winner against Arsenal and now the winner against Manchester United.

But more than anything, it proves the importance of the environment in which you operate. Had Chelsea signed Gordon, do you honestly think it would have gone the same way? He actually started very slowly, one league goal or assist in his first half season. You just didn't notice because everything else was going well at St James Park. Would that have happened at Chelsea too?
Instead Gordon picked the right move at the right time and is getting the right results. Keep this up and he will get his chance for England soon.

Over the last few weeks, as Manchester United became statistically the form team in the Premier League, there were complaints from a number of supporters about why they, and their manager, wasn't being given enough credit.

The best answer was that United didn't pass the eye test. They didn't really look like a team that knew best what to do with the ball and were equally disorganised without it. Look at the teams that they had beaten: Fulham, Luton, Everton, Burnley, Sheffield United, Brentford. Ten Hag's team were capable of squeaking past teams created on far smaller budgets.

And when they face supposed near-peers, Manchester United are out-fought, out-thought and outclassed. This is no knee-jerk reaction, no short-term problem. The last time that United won away at a team in the top eight of the Premier League was October 2021. They have taken three points from a possible 39 since.

Saturday night's defeat might have been the worst of all. Ten Hag's team were abject in every area against a Newcastle team decimated by injuries and fatigue. The only shock is that Newcastle didn't win by three or four goals. And Ten Hag had the temerity to curse a disallowed goal (which was clearly offside) as a reason for his team's inability to take a point.

So what area of this team is working? Anthony Martial is still doing the same thing he always did with roughly the same results and Rasmus Hojlund hasn't scored a Premier League goal yet. Marcus Rashford looks broken to the point of demotivation and there must be serious questions about his relationship with the manager. Bruno Fernandes is an individual spark but he's also a personification of the unpleasantness of this team when they are losing.

In midfield, United had two academy graduates. Kobbie Mainoo is raw and has been hung out to dry. Scott McTominay is not good enough, consistently enough to warrant a starting place in a team with Manchester United's supposed ambition. At the back, United are desperately poor and Harry Maguire is now their best player. Here's a non-fun fact: Manchester United have allowed shots at a quicker rate this season in the league than any of the three relegated sides did last time. They are lucky this isn't much worse.

As if that wasn't bad enough, Ten Hag has frozen out Jadon Sancho, the same is seemingly happening with Raphael Varane, some of the signings he pushed hard for are amongst the club's worst performers and those he inherited appear uninspired by the tactics, the man-management or both.

I take the point that everything is window dressing while the Glazer family remains in charge. But that is not a defence of Ten Hag. He has spent GBP 400m on a transfer list of players largely composed of those who he specifically asked for, and he's made Manchester United worse.

Joao Pedro has had an odd first half season as a Brighton player, given the size of his transfer fee. He scored on the opening weekend of the season and was promptly dropped to the bench for two games. Since then, he has been used primarily as a starter in the Europa League and EFL Cup, but has at least started three other league games. The opponents: Liverpool, Manchester City and Newcastle. Good luck, kid.

The Brazilian is now making a case for a run in the team in all competitions. He has scored four goals in his last three appearances in all competitions, only one of which he started. On Sunday, he threatened to change the game after his introduction at Stamford Bridge and took his goal superbly.

You can understand why Roberto De Zerbi might prefer Evan Ferguson as a centre forward and Kaoru Mitoma on the left when both are available (Pedro can play either role). But when Mitoma is missing or Ferguson is struggling for service, Pedro seems the perfect option to play off a striker or off the left wing. At the very least, he has taken Brighton to the knockout stages of European competition.

It's not West Ham's only problem, given the unimpressed boos and jeers that ran out at half-time in the vague direction of David Moyes. But this season, they have picked up an unbelievably frustrating habit of allowing their concentration to slip immediately after half-time and thus conceding goals in that period.

Let's take a sample of their last 10 league games alone. Moyes' side have allowed goals in the 46th, 49th, 51st, 52nd, 53rd, 55th, 57th and 60th minutes. What's more, those goals have been crucial: 1-0 to 1-1, 0-0 to 0-1, 2-1 to 2-2, 0-0 to 0-1, 0-1 to 0-2, 1-0 to 1-1, 1-1 to 1-2, 1-0 to 1-1.

This kills West Ham's momentum and reduces the ceiling on their performance while they are participating in European football. When accumulated fatigue threatens to be a problem, the last thing you need is to be punched in the gut just as the second half starts.

Try and try and you will succeed. Enzo Fernandez's 43rd shot of this Premier League season ended his goal drought and put Chelsea ahead. His penalty later in the game secured them victory with 10 men.

More important was the leadership Enzo showed in between those goals. Chelsea have an infuriating tendency to make things hard for themselves, but having your captain sent off for two brainless tackles for the second weekend in a row might just be a new low. As last weekend, it threatened to shift the course of the match away from Chelsea.

Enzo was the antidote. He urged calm in those around him. He played with enough intensity to dominate the midfield but without so much that it led to mania in an area of the pitch where Chelsea could have been light. He continued to attempt the progressive passes that avoided Chelsea getting stuck and inviting pressure. Maybe he should be the new captain (until he is inevitably sent off for two bookings)?

It is yet another measure of how quickly Brentford have established themselves in the Premier League that their game with Luton appeared as a Premier League staple vs a Premier League struggler. A reminder, to those who need it: Brentford lost to Luton in the Championship in 2020 and the two clubs faced each other in the fourth tier 14 years ago.

But if there's one thing Thomas Frank's team excel at, it is punishing promoted clubs at home. Their last six home league games against them have ended in victory: 2-1, 2-1, 2-0, 3-2, 3-0 and now 3-1. They are rarely perfect, and struggled to break Luton down before the break, but outclassed them thereafter.

The gap was far greater than the scoreline suggests. Brentford had 27 shots on Saturday. Not only is that their highest ever figure in a Premier League match, it's also their highest in any league game since March 2019 (a game against Sheffield United that, remarkably, they lost 2-0).

Erm, what has happened to Fulham? In their first 11 league games of the season, both teams scored in just four - the exceptions were a 5-1 defeat at Manchester City (that happens), a fun 2-2 draw with Arsenal, a 3-1 win over Sheffield United and a fairly tedious 1-1 draw at Brighton.

In the three games since then, Fulham have scored seven goals and conceded nine. They have done so through playing with possession (Wolves) and sitting back and playing on the counter (Liverpool). The positive spin is that they have won one of those games and scored 38 per cent of their league goals in their last 180 minutes.

But there's a but. This has never been how Marco Silva prefers his teams to operate, a manager who demands control and intelligent risk management. This suggests that even Silva is unsure quite what is happening.

To repeat a point we made earlier in the season, Fulham were bailed out last season by the consistent excellence of Bernd Leno, who overperformed (xG vs goals conceded) more than any other goalkeeper in the Premier League. Fulham have allowed 21 shots on target over their last three games alone. You cannot keep expecting a goalkeeper to cover up all defensive sins.

A draw gained rather than two dropped, given the recent run, given that they were behind and given that Palace were barely able to attack at all during the first half. That goal did indeed come from a wretched error by a West Ham defender. If you are struggling to create chances without your best playmaker, taking the ones handed to you on a plate is crucial.

Still, it's worth giving a little bit of love to Odsonne Edouard, and not only because he still had a fair amount to do when he got the ball. Last season, Edouard managed six league goals all season as he tended to rotate with Jean-Philippe Mateta and Wilfried Zaha took a high number of shots and a high amount of attacking responsibility. This season, Edouard has got six goals already.

He's not perfect, of course, but Edouard is too often forced to feed on crumbs and gruel in this team. He ranked outside the top 50 shot-to-goal ratios in the Premier League before this weekend, but then that's because so many of those chances are blocked or have to be taken quickly because he lacks support. Feed him more and Palace would surely reap the rewards.

There is no shame in defeat at the Emirates, and Wolves' second-half response was actually wholly positive. It reminded of Arsenal's 2-1 home win over Forest on the first weekend of the season, a 2-0 half-time lead that provoked complacency and late panic. We should congratulate Wolves for causing that panic.

But if there is one conclusion to draw, it is about Wolves' midfield because Boubacar Traore was probably the worst player on the pitch against Arsenal. Because of that, Jean-Ricner Bellegarde had to stay deeper to protect the defence and so Wolves lost most of their attacking impetus from midfield. Against Tottenham last month, Bellagarde had 25 touches in the final third; here, just eight.

Mario Lemina ranks first for tackles of any Wolves midfielder this season and first of all players for interceptions. The second highest midfield contributor at Molineux by both of those measures is Joao Gomes. You can hope to sit back and soak up pressure (the right way to play against Arsenal) with one of those missing, but not with both unavailable.

If this is to be the end of Steve Cooper at Nottingham Forest, it is desperately sad that it has ended this way. Cooper has done so much for this club, taking them from the bottom of the Championship to Premier League safety, and through it all he has made them fight for their lives at home. On Saturday evening, that fight looked lost. Forest whimpered to a 1-0 home defeat to Everton.

Cooper has certainly made mistakes - he is in his fifth season of senior management - and he may well pay for them with his job, but it is important to make two points here. The first focuses on the amount of upheaval at Forest, last season and this. Forest has rarely been a steady ship over the past decade, but Cooper was the one who somehow managed to control the madness.

Over this summer, Forest signed 14 new players and 11 of them arrived after the beginning of August. Forest have used six different central defensive combinations in 14 games and seven different combinations in central midfield. They have lost their best attacker to injury - Forest haven't won any of their last 10 games without Taiwo Awoniyi and Chris Wood isn't up to the task.

Secondly, Cooper made a change deep in the soul of Forest supporters. For so long, a list of managers of various personality types and tactical philosophies tried and failed to reconnect the disparate strands of a football club with too much history and not enough future. He got it, when so many others didn't. He made supporters proud and made them like their club again as well as love it so deeply.

You do have to stay in the Premier League, because Forest have spent too much money for anything else to be considered. But seasons follow seasons and always will. What matters, what really sticks out when you're old and grey and staring at the pitch 90 minutes before kick off and reflecting upon who made this all mean the most, are the people who made you fall in love again. Steve Cooper did that, and they will be forever grateful for it.

One of the greatest elements of getting a new manager, with completely new ideas, is discovering which of the players that manager inherits enjoys a rapid boost in performance. At Bournemouth right now, that player is Ryan Christie.

I'll happily admit that I didn't see this coming. Christie was ostensibly signed as a winger or advanced central midfielder from Celtic, and did OK in that role but not much more. He's now playing in a two-man midfield next to Lewis Cook. It took him a while to settle in, which I wrongly interpreted as him not being suited to the role, but against Aston Villa he was probably the best player on the pitch (although Emi Martinez had a bigger impact upon the result).

It was close to the perfect midfield performance. Christie made six tackles, more than any teammate. He made clearances when he needed to. He touched the ball more than any of his teammates. His passing success was better than everyone but Dominic Solanke, who only attempted 10 all game. He created three chances. He got an assist. If every Bournemouth player gets the same lift from Andoni Iraola, Bournemouth will be absolutely fine.

A decent little run ends at the worst possible time. Luton play Arsenal, Manchester City and Newcastle in three of their four games before Christmas. If they had got something at Brentford, they might have entered that period with some momentum. Now it's fear that clothes them again.

Rob Edwards admitted after Saturday's defeat to Brentford that his team were far below their best with the ball and invited pressure, but even his compliments on Luton's off-the-ball work were a little generous. They allowed Brentford to have 27 shots, more than they have faced in any other game this season.

But the loss of Tom Lockyer was the biggest issue. The response to Lockyer's absence in the play-off final is what got Luton here, but his half-time substitution with a back injury caused two goals to be conceded in 12 minutes. With an injury sustained by Teden Mengi in the same game and Marvelous Nakamba and Alfie Doughty already missing, Luton should be fearful. This squad is not deep enough to miss vital parts.

Everton's early life under Sean Dyche was surprising. They tended to concede more goals than we expected and thus were unable to grind out results. Eventually, Dyche worked through those teething problems. From the beginning of February onwards, Everton won four home games (Arsenal, Leeds, Brentford and Bournemouth) 1-0. It was fitting that that score kept them up on the final day.

This season, more surprises. Everton have only won one of their seven home games, but they have established themselves as an elite away team - only Tottenham have picked up more points. Interestingly, the 1-0s are back too, at West Ham and now Nottingham Forest.

But then perhaps there is a theme here after all. The three games in which Everton have had the most possession this season (Luton, Sheffield United and Manchester United) have returned a single point and that was the only away point Sheffield United have picked up all season.

The four games in which they have had the least possession against non-elite teams (so we're leaving out Arsenal and Liverpool here, where the quality gap was the difference) have returned 10 points and nine of those came away from home. The theory is obvious: Dyche feels more obliged to be more proactive at Goodison and Everton can come unstuck. Away from home, he plays his way and gets it done.

You can go right here to read a longer piece about Saturday afternoon at Turf Moor but, after a magnificent result, I thought that it was also important to note how Vincent Kompany has searched for different ways to get his attack firing. It is true that Kompany is not prepared to compromise on his tactical principles, and nor should he, but there have been tweaks that he deserves credit for.

Burnley started the season with a 4-4-2, but changed it after heavy defeats to Aston Villa and Tottenham to provide more bodies in central midfield. In that shape (which also didn't really work), Kompany would start one striker flanked by two wingers, usually Luca Koleosho plus one more. Koleosho is easily the brightest aspect of this Burnley season to date.

The absence of Lyle Foster, given leave of absence with mental health issues, persuaded Kompany to try something else. In came Jay Rodriguez, before then largely restricted to EFL Cup appearances. But Rodriguez needs a strike partner, so Kompany went back to 4-4-2 again. Crosses come into the box for Rodriguez (see the first goal on Saturday) and the two wide players are more natural wingers. Jacob Bruun Larsen started his first league game of the season on Saturday and also scored.

We don't know if this is the answer yet. To repeat a point made in the match piece, Burnley have won two league matches this season and both were fixtures that they also won last season. Does that mean they're good enough for the Premier League, or simply too good for the Championship?

But Rodriguez is worth sticking with because he at least possesses the successful Premier League experience almost everyone behind him lacks. If he and a strike partner can hold up the ball and bring wingers into player, Burnley can become a little more functional and, with it, a little more effective too.

Promotion brought great joy to these supporters, but this is their second successive depressing Premier League season and the fun sure begins to wear off during cold away trips when you come back with nothing but a headache and bad mood.

There is a futility to an exercise for which the entire point is to offer escape. By the end, those that have stayed on only did so to offer a final, frank, 'fk'-filled assessment to those who they believe have let them down. These were heroes once and once wasn't long ago.

Let's be blunt: this was one of the worst away performances I can remember watching in the Premier League. Against a team who had lost seven straight home league games, you keep it tight and get the home fans frustrated. Sheffield United conceded after 15 seconds.
When they needed a response, they conceded again. When they asked for a striker to hold up the ball, he was sent off for two elbows in nine minutes. And that was before the second-half collapse.
Paul Heckingbottom is now on his way out, but this is nothing other than deckchair rearrangement.

The most depressing thing of the whole afternoon was that full-time reaction from supporters, fully understandable but still damning. This will be a long old winter if the supporters cannot trust the players or managers to cope in their current surroundings.

title: England made two big errors that doomed this West Indies series before it began
lead: Decision not to hand Jos Buttler and Sam Curran a rest is symptomatic of a chaotic and leaderless team in need of a new direction
author: Chris Stocks

body.text: After England crashed out of the Cricket World Cup following a shambolic campaign in India, coach Matthew Mott insisted he had learned lessons.
The Australian was unwilling to share those learnings in public, shrugging off concerns that fans would maybe like to hear how he was going to turn things around with a dismissive: 'Whatever.'

Rob Key, England's managing director of cricket, then threw a protective cloak around Mott by taking sole responsibility for a World Cup defence so bad that the holders were eliminated with two weeks of the tournament still to run.

Yet after England sunk to a new low in Antigua on Sunday when they were defeated by a West Indies team who were not even good enough to qualify for the World Cup, you do wonder whether Mott was just bluffing and the reason he was so unwilling to share his wisdom in public is because he is actually horribly out of his depth.

One of the first things Mott should have noted after the shambles in India was that Jos Buttler, his captain, needed to be taken out of the firing line. There is no question Buttler should remain in his position. He deserves a chance to turn things around. But a man who looked haunted during the World Cup fiasco barely had a chance to unpack his suitcase before being tasked with leading the team on this tour of the Caribbean.

And Buttler's performance in the opening ODI, scoring three from 13 balls and looking powerless to change things in the field as the West Indies chased down 326, told of a player who looks like he definitely needs a break.
Buttler is England's greatest white-ball batter but his confidence is shot after a World Cup in which he averaged just 15.

The sensible option would have been to tell him to spend another 10 days or so at home and come out refreshed for the five T20s that follow against the West Indies. Ollie Pope or Zak Crawley could have captained the ODI team for these three matches.

Then Buttler, energised by the extra time at home and a change of format, could have started afresh for a series that will be a vital building block ahead of next summer's T20 World Cup in the Caribbean and the USA.
Instead, England's captain is being forced to relive his Indian nightmare.

It needed a strong coach with respect and authority to demand Buttler be rested for this ODI series. Key would have needed to be persuaded. Unfortunately, Mott is in a weak position after what happened in India. He cannot really demand anything.
So we are where we are right now - England surveying the wreckage of another humiliating defeat against opposition who are a whopping 16 points off Afghanistan in the latest ODI rankings.

This could be written off as one of those things had England not had such a poor World Cup. But during a tournament when so many bad decisions and panicked selections took place, the leadership of Mott did not stand up to scrutiny.

As the results got worse, the dissenting voices became louder. Informfully heard reservations and concerns from multiple sources about Mott's leadership during the tournament. A picture of a rudderless, chaotic camp emerged.
This tour of the Caribbean was meant to be a fresh start with a new group only containing six players from the World Cup.
Yet it was the same old story in game one. Of course, Shai Hope produced a wonderful match-winning century to lead his team to their record ODI chase against England.
Hope was as magnificent as Sam Curran was terrible, the left-arm seamer returning 98 for no wicket from his 9.5 overs - the most expensive bowling figures in England's ODI history.
Like Buttler, Curran should not be playing in this series. Having been deemed unselectable three games into the World Cup, he too should have been taken out of the firing line.
Instead, a player who took two for 140 in 17.2 overs across his three matches at the World Cup has now been scarred by this latest horror show.

The brains trust - led by Mott - made that call and it risks harming England's T20 World Cup chances next summer given Curran was player of the tournament in Australia last year. He is only human. Like Buttler, his confidence must be shot.

There was also the baffling call not to bowl Will Jacks at all on Sunday in a game where spinners - led by Rehan Ahmed's encouraging two for 40 - prospered. Jacks bowled 54 overs during the two Tests he played in Pakistan last winter. Whose decision was it to overlook him in Antigua? You can't think it was solely down to Buttler. Was this pre-planned by Coach Calamity?
There were some positives, noticeably the opening partnership between Jacks and Phil Salt. But given the result, England cannot take too much away from this.

They are good enough to still come back and win the series. Yet even if they do, can we trust this leadership group led by Mott not to buckle again when the pressure is cranked up at next year's T20 World Cup?

title: Courtney Lawes: Why I want to play for Lions again but won't make England return
lead: Ex-England flanker keen to 'complete the set' in Australia 2025
author: Hugh Godwin

body.text: Courtney Lawes has declared himself open to touring with the British and  Irish Lions when they go to Australia in 2025, despite the much-admired flanker retiring from international rugby after the recent World Cup.
But Lawes on Tuesday slapped down any talk of reversing his retirement decision to help England through a deepening injury crisis in the back row in the Six Nations in the new year.

Northampton Saints great Lawes drew a line under his England days with a 105th cap for his country in the semi-final defeat to South Africa in Paris last month, citing his desire to spend more time with his wife and four young children.
And the 34-year-old has yet to decide on the future with his club beyond the end of this season.

But when asked on Tuesday about the possibility of a third Lions tour, having featured in each of the past five Tests in New Zealand in 2017 and South Africa in 2021, Lawes said: 'If I got another Lions call I would probably do that, yeah, yeah.
'I would get to complete the set, I have done two and doing Australia, which is one of my favourite places to tour, would be cool.'

England, who will pick a Six Nations squad in January, already had back-rowers Tom Curry, Ben Earl, George Martin, Zach Mercer and Ted Hill injured when they suffered fresh problems over the weekend, with Lawes's Northampton teammate Lewis Ludlam needing a scan on Tuesday on an ankle sprain, and Saracens' Tom Willis also requiring a scan. Willis's brother Jack and Sam Simmonds are off limits playing for clubs in France.

Lawes was not backing himself for Lions duty in 2025, given 'the amount of good back-rowers we have got now in Great Britain and Ireland', but on the other hand he was 'pretty surprised' when he was named in the Lions squad for the 2021 tour, on the back of a run of injuries, and having not received the preliminary email enquiring after his availability. He went on to start all three Tests at No 6 in South Africa, having been a replacement lock in the second and third Tests in New Zealand in 2017.

England flanker Neil Back became the oldest Test Lion at 36 years and 174 days of age in 2005, despite having retired from international rugby the previous year. Lawrence Dallaglio was another on that tour to have answered the Lions' call at a time when he had ruled himself out of England duty.
Lawes would be 36 years and 146 days at the time of the first Test in Australia in July 2025.
'Playing for England is special to me as well,' Lawes explained.

'But playing for England you are at home for two months, then you are away for two months, then you are home and you never really get a chance to settle in and create any structure in your life for you and your kids. A Lions tour is once every four years and is just a different occasion. If I was to go on it, I would definitely bring the family out for the whole time.

'It is my luck we England have got a back-row crisis when I am actually fit. Normally I am part of the back-row crisis! I am a competitive guy, so if I am going to do something, I want to be the best.'

title: Man Utd return to 'hell' - why Galatasaray brings back bad memories
lead: As United return for another vital Champions League tie, the class of 1993 recall the night they faced throat-slitting gestures, broken bus windows, late-night phone calls and a cauldron of noise
author: Pete Hall

body.text: The old Ali Sami Yen Stadium in the Sisli district of Istanbul did not look much. In fact, according to the demolition company who tore it down in 15 days - rather than the 75 allotted to finish the job - in 2010, Galatasaray supporters had escaped disaster 'with the help of God', such was the sorry state of the structure.
Those who had taken part on the pitch were not much safer, either.

'I can remember the lights being switched off in the tunnel after the game and it suddenly went dark,' Mike Phelan, part of the Manchester United team knocked out of the Champions League by Galatasaray on a chastening night in 1993, tells i.
'It felt like a minute but it was probably shorter - and all of a sudden, the lights come back on and we walked into the dressing room.

'I can remember seeing Eric Cantona sat in a corner and Robbo Bryan Robson with some blood on his eye. Robbo was saying he had been hit and Eric was saying somebody had hit him as well. It was one of those situations where everybody got really aggressive. Eric, particularly, was really, really angry.'

Having drawn the first leg 3-3 in an Old Trafford thriller, with Cantona netting a late equaliser to give United hope, Sir Alex Ferguson's European novices travelled to Turkey as firm favourites. Galatasaray were considered a far inferior side.
This week, United prepare for a crucial crash against the same opponents, this time in the much more opulent surroundings of the newly constructed, safety certified Rams Park.
But in November 1993, the Ali Sami Yen and its sea of yellow and red in the stands - that gave the impression opponents had reached the depths of 'Hell' - took no prisoners.
Right from the moment United landed, greeted by thousands of hostile fans holding placards reading 'Welcome to Hell' (or worse), it was clear this was going to an experience like no other.

'I was picking up my bag from underneath the coach,' former defender Gary Pallister, who watched from the stands in the second leg clash due to injury, tells i. 'I was walking through the stunning hotel, most of the lads are maybe 20 to 30 yards ahead of me, I passed this bellboy, he's pushing one of the trolley things, and as I'm walking past him, I just went 'afternoon' or whatever and he just went like that (a throat-slitting gesture).
'I just carried on walking. I was like 'wow, this is a bit different'. That's what we faced most of the trip to be honest.'
When it came to dirty tricks, the locals pulled out all the stops. Down the years we have heard of plenty of tales of fireworks being set off outside team hotels, or even team buses being attacked.
Hotel staff in a five-star establishment? Only for the most special guests.
'Choccy (Brian McClair) said he had banging on his ceiling, so him and Jim McGregor, our physio, went upstairs and found a cleaner just sat there banging on the ceiling.
'But he just looked at them and walked off. It's crazy to think that this kind of stuff goes on.'

'It was top-dollar service and then on the day of the game, it seemed to change into 'get your own food, look after yourself',' Phelan adds. 'The evening before the match, there was a lot of phone calls being made to the rooms. I picked up my phone a couple of times during the night. But match day we thought we were ready to go.'
Home supporters took to their seats six hours before kick-off to stir the cauldron and sharpen their pitchforks.
It worked. Other than a Lee Sharpe disallowed goal, United rarely dared to threaten the home goal, stumbling to a 0-0 stalemate and an unflattering Champions League exit.

As the home players, captained by former Blackburn metronome Tugay, celebrated a famous result, Cantona lost his head, smashing the ball into the turf with his fist after the Swiss referee, Kurt Rothlisberger, had decided to blow his whistle without adding any stoppage time.
The Frenchman was sent off as the scenes began to get ugly. United supporters were treated to an uncompromising police reaction, while some players ended up bleeding by the end of the night.

'Everyone was a bit incensed that an assault had just happened,' Pallister adds. 'We had the coach window put through on the way back. I think it was down near the front of the bus and we went back for part of the journey with the window missing. It was quite a trip for our first Champions League experience.'
The majority of United's current side are no strangers to far-flung European adventures. The task at hand, this time around, is strikingly similar.
Just four points garnered from their opening four group matches leaves them needing a sizeable turnaround to reach the knockout stages of this season's competition.

Two wins from their two final matches, starting in Istanbul, should do it. The experience for the current squad won't be anything like as intimidating as 30 years ago, but just as they did in their impressive weekend win at a febrile Everton, United must thrive in the hostility, in their hour of need.
'In big football matches even now, there are all sort of things so you have to experience if you want to be successful,' Phelan adds.

'We've got to control the game, because you can't control the atmosphere. You might be able to, in a little way, if your retention of the ball is good and you're not making mistakes, control the ball and that can silence the crowd - don't encourage the crowd.

'Everything is a challenge when you're at Manchester United, particularly when you're back in the Champions League and you want to go to the next level. So they have to perform. Istanbul is not somewhere you can go and sort of scrape your way through.'

title: Brighton have unearthed another gem for Chelsea to poach
lead: Arriving on the same day that Enzo Fernandez left, the young Argentine was the Seagulls' star at Stamford Bridge on Sunday
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: Chelsea 3-2 Brighton (Fernandez 17, 65 pen, Colwill 21, Gallagher red card 45  Buonanotte 43, Pedro 90'+2)

STAMFORD BRIDGE - Three points that felt like something. But progress? Hardly, even if Chelsea did prevail after playing more than half the contest with 10 men. The Chelsea players were brimful of emotion at the end of a tense afternoon, as well they might be after only their second Premier League win at Stamford Bridge this season, and just their fourth of 2023.

In a different context three points against Brighton may have meant more, a hefty contribution in the challenge for the title, perhaps. But that is not where Chelsea are. This was another strange day in the evolution of the Todd Boehly project, three points gratefully received but not the fruit of grand designs.

A hostile finale shifted attention from wider questions about the big picture. Referee Craig Pawson had struggled to control the environment throughout and was the architect of significant confusion at the end when mistakenly awarding a penalty to Brighton in the 10th minute of added time. VAR showed what was obvious to most, that the ball whacked Levi Colwill in the face, not the hand.

Brighton, frustrated at their inability to force a result, went full handbags at the final whistle, and Chelsea indulged them with machismo posturing of their own. This, and the three points, of course, meant Mauricio Pochettino did not have to answer for what was an unimaginative, if battling performance.

Chelsea have yet to forge an identity under Pochettino. He accepts this, arguing that relationships must develop, and players grow together before identity can be decided. Thus the most expensively assembled squad in the history of the Premier League necessarily labours with no obvious focal point yet, or big idea. After last week's disintegration at Newcastle any kind of win is welcome. Yet until the introduction of Cole Palmer for Raheem Sterling late in the match there was very little to light the way forward.

'We needed to win the three points,' Pochettino said. 'We are a young team, young players. We need to improve and learn why the Premier League is the best in the world. We want to play well and show that we care. I'm proud. After Newcastle it was tough, and Brighton are a difficult team to play. We are Chelsea and the expectation is to win. But the situation we are in, it is difficult for the players. We have to keep showing we are a team. It takes 12 months in this league to start showing real confidence and grow.'

By that calculation Enzo Fernandez has a month to recover some ground. Eleven months after joining for a Premier League record of GBP 106m Fernandez himself would not claim his first goals for Chelsea were value for money, however welcome they were here. His partnership with Moises Caicedo, only a few million quid cheaper, has yet to yield authority or dominance.
