Pundits (confirmed so far)
Commentators (confirmed so far)
Amazon Prime members will be able to watch the games live on the Prime Video app on their smart TVs, mobile devices and games consoles, among other devices.
An Amazon Prime membership costs GBP 8.99 per month or GBP 95 for the year. New customers can subscribe for a 30-day free trial.

title: Threat to pensions triple lock grows amid Sunak and Starmer 'standoff'
lead: The Conservatives and Labour are 'each waiting for the other to blink' when it comes to their policy on the triple lock, says an ex-minister
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer are 'each waiting for the other to blink' when it comes to setting out their general election manifesto pledges on state pension increases, a former minister has said.
Currently, under the triple-lock policy, the state pension rises each year by the same level as inflation, average earnings or 2.5 per cent, whichever is the highest.
But both the Prime Minister and Labour leader have not committed to maintaining the policy after the next election, which is likely to take place next year, with the cost of the policy spiralling.
There is growing pressure to scrap or reform it, with a recent international report warning that it hadput the public finances in jeopardy.
An ex-minister told Informfully that both parties were involved in a 'Mexican stand off' when it came to devising their approach to the policy.
The minister, who asked to remain anonymous, said: 'It feels like both parties are each waiting for the other to blink.
'Each would love the other to say 'we'd like the state pension to be pegged to just earnings rather than continue the triple lock'. If one said that, the other would be tempted to say, 'so are we.''
The source said that the current triple lock policy 'hoovered up' the pensioner vote but that this came with a 'price tag.'
'The situation is a bit like a Mexican stand-off. Who makes the first move and how does the other person respond? If I was a gambling man I would say they both commit to it,' they added.

The triple-lock policy was first unveiled by the Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government 13 years ago as a mechanism to address high rates of poverty in the UK at the time, and has been maintained by successive governments since.

However, politicians from both the Conservative government and from Labour have suggested that, having achieved its goal of taking many pensioners out of poverty, the mechanism could change to one that is cheaper for the public purse.

Analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies, the independent economic think-tank, suggests that the policy has increased state pension spending by around GBP 11bn a year, compared with if pensions had been upped in line with either prices or earnings since 2010.

And asked while travelling to the COP 28 summit at the weekend whether a continued commitment to the triple lock would be in the next Conservative manifesto, Mr Sunak said: 'I'm definitely not going to start writing the manifesto on the plane, as fun as that would be.'
Starmer, who has also been attending the summit in Dubai, said: 'This Government made the commitment on the triple lock and it's for this Government to keep to its commitment.
'We will set out our position as we get to the election. There is obviously at least one more fiscal event to be had yet, but we will set that out fully before we get to the election.'

It comes after Work and Pensions Secretary Mel Stride conceded the triple lock was 'not sustainable' in the long-term, in an interview in September, while Labour's deputy leader Angela Rayner refused to commit her party to the policy, telling Informfully: 'We will have to see where we are when we get to a general election and we see the finances.'
The Liberal Democrats have already committed to keeping the triple lock and called on other parties to do the same.
In April 2024, the state pension rise will make it worth GBP 221.20 a week for the full, new flat-rate state pension and GBP 169.50 a week for the full, old basic state pension.
Figures from the IFS suggest that by 2050, a reasonable estimate would be that the triple lock will add between GBP 5bn and GBP 45bn a year to state pension spending.

And estimates from the Office for Budget Responsbility (OBR) suggest that by the 2070s, paying for the state pension and associated benefits such as pension credit and winter fuel payments could cost 8.1 per cent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP), up from just under 5 per cent currently.

title: 'My flatmate puts the heating on constantly. Should he pay more towards bills?'
lead: A reader wants to know whether to raise the problem with their housemate
author: Callum Mason

body.text: In our new weekly series, readers can email in with any financial dilemma and enter the Money Moral Maze.

Are your friends racking up big drinks tabs and then trying to split the bill equally, is your partner spending overspending on your joint account? No matter your dilemma, email in anonymously, and i's money and business team will do our best to answer.
This week's dilemma can be found below - email us at money@inews.co.uk with yours.
I live in a three-bedroom flat in Manchester with three others. We all in our 20s, we get on, but we didn't know each other before we moved in, in September.

Most things in the flat are going well, but one of the other two is extremely annoying about the heating. He insists on putting it on almost constantly and also occasionally runs an electric heater in his room as well.
I understand that people feel cold differently, but I know the bill will be racking up, with heating costs so high at the moment and we are splitting the bill in thirds.
Should I raise this, and ask him to contribute more towards the bill, or is this just something I will have to accept?
This is an absolutely classic dilemma - and one that is undoubtedly on the minds of house-sharers up and down the country right now.
This conundrum is not new and has been made worse in the past few years by ballooning energy bills.

I wonder how many friendships have been damaged by the increasing resentment around money, whether it's the person who orders very expensive food then expects everyone to fund the bill equally, people whose parents pay for their house deposit or those angry about their housemates having the heating on a lot.

This issue could also be helped if landlords had to improve the energy efficiency of the homes they rent out - as they were set to be obliged to until very recently - but that's a discussion for another day.
To a certain extent, you have to let certain things go - at least from a financial perspective - when you are sharing your home with someone, as you can't be in full control.

Were they only using the heating a bit more than you thought necessary, my advice would be to leave it, otherwise where does it end? Would you equally apportion bills based on who used the oven more? Who used the most kitchen roll? It'd be never-ending and not good for anyone.

But in this situation, when they are using the heating a lot more - and you have said it is on constantly - this is likely to be costing you a lot. And if you're not feeling the benefit, as you don't want or need it on this much, then that's not fair on you.

Perhaps a good starting point would be to open this up as a conversation. Is there potentially a reason he needs the heating on so much? Is he unaware that he's using it an excessive amount? Did he grow up in a home where the heating was on all the time? It may be worth figuring out his perspective and coming to a compromise.

If this doesn't help, then you are within your rights to have a more direct conversation about it and express your concern over the size of the heating bill and ask if you can work together to lower it. It's a variation on the 'just put a jumper on' theme that all parents know and love.

title: How paying your grandchild's private school fees could help you avoid paying IHT
lead: More grandparents are looking to help their grandchildren with private school fees
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Zoe van der Linden, 40, never thought she'd send her daughter to a private school. But that all changed once Eva, who is seven, reached school age.

'Putting her in private school goes against how I feel,' said Zoe. 'I think everyone should have access to the same education. However, I started to wonder if she is achieving her full potential where she is. She is showing as being very adept academically. The state schools that will develop her in the best way aren't available to us as they aren't close enough.'

Eva, who is currently in state school, started showing strong academic ability, said Zoe. So much so her and her husband, Hugh, decided to investigate the possibility of sending their daughter to private school.  However, cost was an issue.

Although they are both in jobs with good incomes - she works as a senior manager at a fintech firm and he as a financial planner - it will still too much of a stretch. The conversation turned to whether her mother, Helen, would be able to pay instead.

'My husband and I went to my mum about paying for education,' she said. 'It was something she was prepared for as the money she has put by was expected to be used for education - whether that be university or otherwise.'
Zoe and Helen, who is retired, are not the only ones considering making this move.

More grandparents are now covering the cost of school fees for their grandchildren as parents struggle with the rising costs of private schools along with the general increase in costs thanks to inflation.

To see if sending her child to private school was an option, Zoe went to her financial adviser at wealth planner Old Mill, initially thinking she would fund the school fees through her and her partner's income.

While there is currently enough surplus from their salaries to cover the cost, she was concerned about job security and the potential disruption of having to change schools if she andor her husband were to go through a period of unemployment.
In 2022-23, average fees in the UK were GBP 15,655 per year for day pupils, and about GBP 37,000 for boarders.
But while parents may want to help their children, there can be tax implications.

He said: 'We have seen an increase in affluent grandparents now offering some financial support to parents, if appropriate,' said Jonathan Orchard, a chartered financial planner who advised Helen and Zoe.

'This method of providing support, while clearly welcome, can have unintended tax implications and so needs to be thought through very carefully. There is also the opportunity for grandparents to use their generosity to reduce their personal tax burden.'
In Helen's case, he suggested the best way to give the money to Zoe would be to set up a family trust.

A trust is a legal arrangement where a person can gift money for the benefit of another person or group of people.  The trust funds are usually controlled by a trustee (of which the person who gifted the money can be one), and they have the responsibility to act in the best interest of the beneficiaries.
A trust continues to protect the persons assets after death or in the event that they lose capacity to manage their own affairs.
In this scenario, Helen, 73, would make a trust to gift money to Zoe to spend on private education.

Helen, who is retired, has savings that are invested. She also has a self-invested personal pension, more commonly known as SIPP, which she hasn't yet spent, and has earmarked to pass on to her grandchildren.
She has already withdrawn money from her pension that will go towards her granddaughters education.

Orchard added: 'This lump sum, along with some further funds, was gifted into a family trust for the main benefit of Eva, to secure her private education costs, regardless of any change in the parents' circumstances.'
If Helen lives for seven years, to 80, the gift of the money will be outside of her estate and will not be subject to inheritance tax.

Currently, inheritance tax is charged at 40 per cent for properties worth more than GBP 325,000 with an extra GBP 175,000 allowance if the main residence is passed to children or grandchildren. No inheritance tax is due on gifts if you live for seven years after giving them. If you do die within three years of giving them, the gifts could be liable for the full inheritance tax rate of 40 per cent.
The payments out of the trust to fund the school fees will be taxable against Eva instead.
Zoe says it is likely, if she decides to go forwards with a private education, that her mother will end up paying for the whole time, which could be until Year 13, before university.

She said: 'How much it will cost in total will depend. On the lower end, private schools can start at GBP 10,000 but go up to GBP 20,000 a year depending on the term. Depending on my husband and I's earning potential, which will hopefully go up over time, will depend on where Eva may go and for how long.'
This could work out at a cost of potentially upwards of GBP 200,000 if goes to a more expensive school and stays in education until she is 18.
Zoe and her husband have not yet decided on a school for their daughter so do not know the full cost but, if they do find one, will follow Orchard's advice and take the money from the trust.

Jonathan says one of the best ways for grandparents to pay for school fees is via a family Trust. These trusts can provide a secure and efficient way to plan for school fees, offering tax benefits, asset protection, flexibility, and long-term continuity.

title: The state pension is a benefit - here's why it's important we say so
lead: The notion that people collecting their state pension are simply taking back what they previously paid in is wrong
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Last week in chancellor Jeremy Hunt's Autumn Statement, benefits were increased by 6.7 per cent, while the state pension went up by 8.5 per cent.

Except in a way, what really happened is that some benefits went up by 6.7 per cent, and others by 8.5 per cent. This is because, although some people don't like to say it, the state pension is a benefit.

In 2016, a petition calling on the Government to stop labelling the state pension a 'benefit' received over 14,000 signatures, and a brief look on social media will see many responding in the same way to media reports calling it one.
The arguments usually come from pensioners who believe they have 'earned' their state pension, by paying national insurance (NI) contributions throughout their lifetime.

Perhaps they see benefits as some sadly do see them - as a handout - and don't like the premise that what they are getting is in a similar vein. They want to feel as if they have paid their own way, which is understandable, after decades of paying tax.
In reality though, I believe it would be dangerous for us to stop calling the state pension a benefit - and here's why.
Firstly, the fact that some form of contribution is required to claim the state pension is not unique in our benefits system.
While some benefits - non-contributory ones such as personal independence payments (PIP) - don't require people to 'pay in', to the system, others do.
The likes of jobseekers' allowance and employment and support allowance also require NI contributions to be claimed. Should we stop calling these benefits too?
Secondly, the notion that the state pension is 'earned' is wrong. Many people - most in fact - get more back through the state pension than they pay in via NI contributions in their lifetime.
Even beyond this, people on certain working-age benefits such as universal credit, can get NI credits, and therefore the state pension, instead of paying NI as a tax from their salary.
In fact, a little-known rule actually means some people can get it without having a NI number at all, as Informfully has reported.
This is a perfectly reasonable framework, and I'm in no way suggesting there's anything wrong with how it operates.
But the pension isn't a pot - you aren't simply taking out what you put in when you receive your state pension.

Suggesting that the state pension is simply 'reclaiming what you are owed' is moving on to risky ground, because it erases the experiences all those people who are paid it, but did not make direct contributions via NI, misrepresenting how it works.

Calling the state pension a 'benefit' is right. Maybe those who oppose doing so should interrogate their own motivations? Could it possibly be a subconscious (or otherwise) prejudice towards people who 'claim benefits'?
If it is, perhaps it's this attitude that needs to change, rather than the language we use to describe what is the biggest benefit of all.

title: How I Manage My Money: Technical officer, 28, on GBP 3.1k a month, spends hours researching stocks
lead: In this week's How I Manage My Money, chief technical officer and avid investor James Goodwin shares his experiences of managing his personal finances
author: Jane Denton

body.text: In our How I Manage My Money series we aim to find out how people in the UK are spending, saving and investing money to meet their costs and achieve their goals.

This week we speak to James Goodwin, 28, a chief technical officer at a small software and telecoms company, who lives in York with his wife, HuiQiong, 31. James is a keen investor and has around GBP 40,000 tied up in six stocks via a stocks and shares Isa. James spends more than 100 hours researching any stock before taking the plunge and investing.

Once his portfolio is closer to the GBP 500,000 mark, he would like to become a full-time investor. Ideally, he'd like his portfolio to reach a value of GBP 1m by 2035. James describes himself as contrarian and isn't afraid to consider out of favour stocks.
My monthly income: I earn GBP 3,168 after tax and student loan repayments from my full-time job. My wife brings in around GBP 2,300 after tax from two jobs.

My monthly outgoings: Mortgage, GBP 1,000, groceries and takeaways, GBP 500, gas and electric, GBP 37, water, GBP 30, public transport to get to and from the office, GBP 100, broadband, GBP 60, mobile phone bill, GBP 30, premium YouTube, GBP 11.99, Amazon Prime, GBP 10, my wife's gym membership, GBP 40, items for the cat, including food and insurance, GBP 100, entertainment, including going to the cinema and eating out, GBP 200. We probably spend around GBP 3,000 on travel each year, as HuiQiong's family live in China.
We generally manage to save around GBP 2,000 per month.

I grew up in a small village in Norfolk, 10 miles from the nearest town. My parents were divorced and my brother and I lived with my mother, who was earning minimum wage. She relied on benefit payments from the Government and child maintenance payments from my father to support us.
I did well academically and went to the University of York to study physics at undergraduate level, before studying for a Masters in IT.

I did particularly well in my physics degree and got offered a PhD studentship at Cambridge University, but turned it down due to my distaste for elitism. I wanted my career success to be due to my own merit rather than attending the 'right' university.

I started working in software engineering after graduating and am now the chief technical officer at a small software and telecoms company. My gross annual salary is GBP 65,000, plus a variable bonus that's typically between GBP 3,000 to GBP 5,000.

I made my first investment in 2020 before the start of the pandemic. I took a course in business accounting to help me better understand the financial statements of firms I was interested in. I had a few thousand pounds saved and purchased some shares in AMD, the chip manufacturer.

As a consumer of their products, I'd seen a dramatic improvement in their technology which significantly closed the gap between them and their main competitor, Intel; but the market had yet to pick this up. I got pretty lucky with the timing, because within a few months my investment had doubled.

I spend more than 100 hours doing due diligence before I make an investment. However, if you add up the time spent doing ongoing due diligence, it probably adds up to over 300 hours for some of my holdings. If I was doing it full-time, this figure would likely be even higher, but I have to cut back on some things to make it manageable. Time constraints are the reason I only have six holdings at present. I'd like to own a few more.

I'm comfortable taking calculated risks, and see concentrated investing in publicly listed companies as a lower risk form of entrepreneurship. I'd say I'm naturally quite contrarian, so holding something that's completely out of favour with the market is no issue for me.

I now have holdings in the following companies: Aviva, Fuller, Smith and  Turner, Taylor Maritime Investments, Ecora Resources, tinyBuild and Warner Bros. Discovery. They are all held in a stocks and shares ISA with AJ Bell. I tend to build up new positions over a few months, but then add to individual positions in my portfolio when their prices fall.

My investments range from GBP 5,000 to GBP 20,000, though the current values look more balanced as some investments have gone up, while others have come down. The portfolio has a value of around GBP 40,000. In terms of returns, I've had mixed results. For example, Aviva has doubled since my initial purchase, but tinyBuild, an American published of games, has halved from my average purchase price.

Being an individual investor, I take a long-term perspective, so falls in the short-term don't really matter as long as the investment thesis is still intact, and the business is robust enough to survive a downturn. I expect it to take up to five years for the market's view to align with my view on a company, and since the majority of the shares in my portfolio were purchased within the last two years, it's still pretty early days.

Firm Returns is a newsletter I started in November 2022 as a way of increasing the due diligence I was doing on companies I invested in, and making me publicly accountable for everything I buy and sell. To begin with I was doing long-form write-ups of between 5,000 to 10,000 words, on individual companies, every one to two months. But I'm now doing shorter weekly newsletters that provide ongoing coverage of the companies I hold in my portfolio.

I've gained far more from Firm Returns than I expected. I have built up a substantial investor network and had direct access to the management of several companies in my portfolio. I have no intention of monetising the newsletter.

I've maxed out my stocks and shares ISA allowance during the past couple of years, but will probably reduce this to GBP 10,000 per year going forward. My wife wants to build up a larger cash balance and diversify into other assets.

I would like my GBP 40,000 portfolio of investments to reach GBP 1m by 2035. I think this is possible, but would require my holdings to meet or exceed my highest expectations, which is somewhat unlikely. I hope to hit the GBP 1m mark eventually, but 2035 is pretty optimistic.

I have absolutely no interest in options like Vanguard LifeStrategy funds, whichcombine multiple individual index funds into one fund portfolio. I want to know everything I own, and doubt I'd like most of their holdings if I looked. Cryptocurrency is something I've looked into from a technology standpoint, but it's too speculative for me to invest in.

Despite the benefits of investing in a pension, I prefer to invest in accounts that I can access at any time such as an ISA. I don't like the fact that there's a Government-mandated minimum retirement age, which I expect to have increased substantially by the time I reach it. On these grounds, I just put in as much as my employer will match, which is around 3 per cent.

Money is freedom and security, so incredibly important. I would probably live fairly modestly even if I was rich. My perspective is that everyone who is born without money is effectively a modern day slave who can either die a slave or earn enough to buy their freedom. I'm intent on the latter.

In future, I'd like to become a full-time investor managing my own money. I would also consider starting my own business venture at some point. Around the GBP 500,000 level is probably the threshold from which I could consider managing my investment portfolio full-time, especially if all my investments are held in an ISA, so the returns are tax-free. I hope to reach this point within the next decade.

title: Christmas dinner essentials cost up to 26% more this year
lead: Key ingredients from parsnips to potatoes soar in price as food inflation remains high (but sprouts slump)
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Households across the country could be forced to ditch some of their favourite Christmas dinner dishes and delicacies after key ingredients after they shot up in price.

The average cost of feeding a family of four for Christmas is now GBP 31.71, an increase of only 1.3 per cent when compared to a year ago. However, some elements of the festive meal are much pricier, new data shows.
Cranberry sauce is now 26.5 per cent more expensive, costing GBP 1.29 for four servings, according to research from market data company Kantar.
Frozen turkey, is the most expensive item on the menu, costing GBP 14.76, up 3.1 per cent since last year.
The cost of vegetables have also seen a significant hike.
Carrots are up 12.8 per cent, costing GBP 0.44, while the price of potatoes has increased by 7.7 per cent at GBP 1.40.
Cauliflower has risen by 3.9 per cent, to GBP 1.07 for four servings, while parsnips are 3.3 per cent pricier, costing GBP 0.62.
Not all Christmas essentials have seen an increase - and some have actually reduced in price.
These include Brussels sprouts down 4.3 per cent at GBP 0.88, and Christmas puddings which are cheaper by 2.4 per cent, at GBP 3.19.
Sparkling wine has also seen a reduction of 5.9 per cent, costing a total of GBP 7.01 for four glasses.

Grocery inflation stands at 9.6 per cent for the 12-week period ending on 26 November, according to Kantar. This is compared to the highest rate of 17.1 per cent, recorded in the 12 weeks to 14 May this year.
However, it doesn't mean prices are coming down - just that, overall, they are rising at a slower rate than before, meaning prices are still higher than in previous years.
To entice more customers, supermarkets are now putting the emphasis on own-label lines and promotions to attract people through their doors, Kantar said.
Its data shows that in the latest four-week period, spending on offers hit its highest level in more than two years at 28.4 per cent.

Fraser McKevitt, head of retail and consumer insight at Kantar, said: 'The amount of money spent on deals usually leaps in the run-up to Christmas, but this year is already looking a bit different. We're well above 2022 levels, with customers making an additional GBP 180m in savings this November versus 12 months ago.
'Brands have benefited from the boost in offers and have now edged ahead of their own-label counterparts, growing sales by 6.5 per cent compared to 6.4 per cent for retailer lines.'

However, own-label products are still doing very well, Kantar said, with sales of these products up by 15.4 per cent year on year, with wine, chilled ready meals and fresh beef among the big winners last month.
McKevitt added: 'We're likely to see a seasonal jump in premium stuffing, sausage meat and Christmas puddings over the coming weeks.'

Shopping around could help customers save on key items, experts say, with separate research from Which? earlier this month showing that Aldi and Lidl are joint-cheapest for Christmas dinner essentials.
It analysed the prices of 12 popular festive foods including turkey, trimmings and a Christmas pudding at seven major supermarkets - Aldi, Asda, Lidl, Morrisons, Sainsbury's, Tesco and Waitrose.

Which? found that the medium turkey crown was the most expensive item across all of the supermarkets, however it was cheapest at Aldi and Lidl, costing GBP 15.49. Waitrose was the most expensive at GBP 26 on average.

It added that the biggest percentage price difference was for cranberry sauce. At Aldi, whole cranberry sauce (200g) was 59p while at Waitrose, own-brand Waitrose Wild cranberry sauce (205g) was GBP 2.20 - 270 per cent more expensive.

title: I've discovered my pension is invested in cigarette and arms firms - should I move my money?
lead: Money Moral Maze: This week, a reader is stuck on what to do now they're aware that their pension isn't ethically invested
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: In our new weekly series, readers can email in with any financial dilemma and enter the Money Moral Maze.

Are your friends racking up big drinks tabs and then trying to split the bill equally, is your partner spending overspending on your joint account? No matter your dilemma, email in anonymously, and i's money and business team will do our best to answer.
This week's dilemma can be found below - email us at money@inews.co.uk with yours.

I've got my money invested in a fund that performs well - I'm happy with the returns I'm getting and it's setting me up well for my retirement. I've never really paid much attention to where the money is invested but through a friend I've realised recently that it puts money into both cigarette and arms firms.
I'm less happy about this. Clearly I don't support things that threaten others' lives. What should I do? Should I look to put my money elsewhere?

I have one answer to this question that I would like to give, which is 'yes, you should look to move the money elsewhere.' And then I have the other more honest answer which is that I do have money invested in some of these areas.
Before my house purchase decimated my (mostly invested) savings, they were in a well-known fund. It made my savings grow very nicely, and I avoided looking too hard into what it invests in.

I do believe we should not invest in anything that kills people - which means tobacco firms, arms manufacturers - but I'm a hypocrite, as the fund above has money in in tobacco, and if I looked at the fact sheet in more detail (which would tell me what else it was invested in) I would not be surprised if there was an arms manufacturer in there too.

My excuse (and I'm aware it is one) is that I have been late to pension saving, only starting properly only in my late thirties, and I'm very much in catch-up mode. So my savings at the moment are focused on profit.
This means ethical investing isn't my number one consideration, partly because I don't feel financially comfortable enough to remove profit as the primary goal.

I'm not alone: ESG investing (ethical, social and governance) boomed over the pandemic years when several prominent funds, like Baillie Gifford's Positive Change one - which I have also been invested in - saw returns that rivalled any of the non-ethical ones.
Cue loads of money pouring in, but the question is: were people interested in ethical investing, or were they following the money? The likely answer is both.

My get out clause is that my husband is a scrupulously ethical investor and I like to think that gives me a little slack to focus on profit for the family. It's not right, but then it's hard not to focus on the money in tough economic times.
I suppose part of you wishes you had never found out where the fund you have invested in puts its money. That way, you would have been able to continue with your strong returns in blissful ignorance.
The reality is though, ethics are clearly important to you, as you state in your dilemma. Now you know where your money is, you're not going to be truly happy with the returns it makes.

The situation is this: investing ethically and making good returns are not mutually exclusive. There are plenty of strong options for investors with a social conscience, as outlined in Jessie's answer above. Why not take some time to have a look at these options, and consider one of them instead?
If you're having to pose the question of whether you should move your money, it suggests to me that your decision is already partly made.

Financial returns are very important, and you may question why you would change a winning formula, but it sounds like you don't want to be backing organisations that you do not agree with. Why not back those you do agree with instead, while still making money as you have been doing.
You'll feel better about it in the long run.

title: Interest rate decision: Inflation is more stubborn than any toddler, and the Bank is the exasperated parent
lead: The Bank of England has opted to hold interest rates - but don't expect them to come down soon
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: We knew the type of inflation we were dealing with was stubborn, but today gives us an idea of how much so so. We're talking a three-year-old who is refusing to eat their spinach levels of stubborn. And as any parent knows, once you're in this position, you are in trouble.

Keeping with this analogy, the Bank  of England is the exasperated, somewhat powerless parent. Looking at the data published alongside its decision to keep the base rate at 5.25 per cent, it shows that even were it to decrease the base rate possibly even several times, it would not significantly change the dial on inflation next year.

The figures on the economy were quite a bit gloomier than expected, and we're now now due to hit the 2 per cent target until the end of 2025, six months later than forecast only in August. Were the base rate to stay where it is, the country goes into recession next year and stays there for 12 months. If the Bank reduces the base rate, growth flat lines: the table outlining this scenario is a depressing sea of zeros. I for one am not going to be rushing out to book a holiday in the Caribbean any time soon given that a flatlining economy is the more positive of the two outcomes we're looking at.

The monetary policy committee (the rate setting committee within the Bank, often known as the MPC) noted that a 'restrictive policy stance' - code for higher rates - is 'likely to be warranted for an extended period of time'. The MPC added that 'a further rise in bank rate remained a possibility'.

So what does all of this mean for our wallets? Next year will be tough: rates will stay high, unemployment is likely to go up, the pay increases many have been able to obtain will become harder to come by. The Bank estimates that half of the impact of increasing rates is yet to feed through in the economy, which means many of us haven't remortgaged yet so are living on old money that hasn't been strangled by the rate rises.

My take home message from today is to make sure you are doing all the boring, sensible things.  When interest rates were low, any fool was able to make money from the stock market and feel like Warren Buffet.
Now you don't need to risk your money to make a decent return; standard savings accounts are beating yields of many investment funds and this is likely to continue.

That we are in an unprecedented situation is underlined by the fact that we are seeing house prices going down, rising unemployment, very gloomy news on GDP and falling inflation. and the Bank is still not opting to cut rates.

Save as much as you can - one of the worst consequences of the 15 years of rock bottom rates is that we were deprived of any incentive to save, which is the best insurance policy I know of to allow you to sleep at night even when the economy weakens.
We are in a new world. Higher interest rates mean smaller mortgages and more expensive borrowing everywhere, and a reassessment of the risks we take with our money.
Sometimes boring is best - adults as well as kids will need to eat their spinach. Looking at the tables compiled by the economy wonks at the Bank of England, that is especially true now.

title: After 10 years renting my flat, I was hit with a 'revenge eviction'
lead: Adam and his wife, Laura, were served a Section 21 notice, something many want banned
author: Charlotte Gill

body.text: For almost 10 years, Adam and his wife, Laura, have rented the same property near Bristol. They had, Adam thought, 'a reasonable relationship' with their landlord.

That's until one day in June this year, when the landlord called Adam up to say his mortgage was coming to an end. He wanted to sell the house this December. There was a silver lining to the news, though: the landlord offered Adam and Laura first refusal on the property.

Of the offer on the table, Adam says: 'He got three valuations from estate agents and all came back with GBP 205,000 to GBP 210,000. He then said the lowest he would accept is GBP 200,000 for the flat, which sounds fair, but we had and still have problems that needed doing.'

These problems weren't minor to say the least. The property had previously had rats in the loft, which 'nibbled through a bunch of electric wires and knocked the boiler off'. Although the boiler was replaced, 'it kept cutting out and not working', so Adam and Laura pushed for a further resolution. The landlord told them that he'd get round to fixing it at some point.
'That was about four-and-a-half-years ago', Adam tells i, claiming that they weren't given a gas-safety certificate, which landlords are legally required to provide.

The couple's extractor fan also needs repairing. While the landlord told them 'over a year ago' that he would do so, 'still no action has been taken' according to Adam. He and Laura made clear that these issues needed to be sorted if they were to buy the house.
Then, 'out of the blue', the couple received a Section 21 notice (otherwise known as a 'no-fault eviction') advising them that they have until 11 December to get out of the property.

'We have told him about all these problems in person and in an email, he has told us that he won't fix them until we move, which is illegal and is called retaliation eviction or revenge eviction,' Adam says.
He believes the landlord is trying to pressure them into a purchase; that, or trying to get rid of them, so that the landlord can sell the house quickly. He seems in a rush to offload the property.

Since receiving the Section 21 notice, Adam and Laura have been plagued by even more housing issues. Despite not wanting to do any of the major repairs needed, the landlord tried to put a new door in, asking the couple for their keys back. Moreover, they are unable to work out what happened to the GBP 500 deposit they put down to rent the property many years ago, which they say may not have been put in a housing deposit scheme.

Adam and Laura have been speaking to Shelter, as well as a solicitor, who has told them that they can ask for the deposit back and up to three times the amount in compensation, due to it not being correctly processed.
Adam and Laura are not looking forward to the prospect of moving out and the situation has added a huge amount of stress to their lives.

Adam, who runs a cleaning business, says: 'We are both very concerned and it's affected us not only mentally but physically, recently my wife and I have been very stressed which has affected our health, too. We are both worrying about moving.'

He adds that the 'shortage of houses in the area adds pressure'. Nearby Bristol has fast become one of the most popular parts of the UK to live in, becoming the most expensive city to rent in outside of London.

Adam and Laura aren't anomalies in their housing situation. According to research from Shelter, around 814,000 private renters in England, the equivalent of one in 10, are at risk of losing their homes through Section 21 notices this winter. Around 3.5 million tenants now say they're worried about becoming homeless due to housing costs, with more than 31 per cent having to borrow money to afford their rent.

Although the Government is being urged to speed up the ban of Section 21 evictions, there's still debate over whether this is having paradoxical effects, with landlords pre-emptively selling and the subsequent properties being snapped up by cash buyers. Unfortunately, by the time any significant action is taken to fix the housing crisis, it's probable that there will be many more economic victims like Adam and Laura.

title: When the cheapest time to buy a house will be, according to experts
lead: New forecasts revealed alongside the Autumn Statement show what will happen to property prices in the future
author: Callum Mason

body.text: House prices will reach their lowest point at the end of 2024, according to a forecast from the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR).

The body, which provided its forecast for the Treasury ahead of yesterday's Autumn Statement, said that house prices will grow by 0.9 per cent in 2023 before falling by 4.7 per cent in 2024, reaching their lowest level in the last three months of next year.
After this, it expects prices to recover slowly, reaching their late 2022 peak levels in the second half of 2027.

With property prices reaching an expected low in a year's time, before rising throughout 2025 and beyond, is the end of next year, or the start of 2025, the best time to secure a home for the cheapest price? Informfully has looked at the evidence below.
Will property prices bottom out at the end of next year?
The price of the average UK home will 'reach a low of around GBP 266,000 at its trough in the final quarter of 2024', according to the OBR's forecast.
It is not the only forecaster, and others have done their own projections for prices too.

Earlier this month, a forecast from estate agency Savills suggested prices would also reach their lowest level in 2024, and added that projected cuts to interest rates would give 'more capacity for price growth in the mainstream market from the end of next year'.
The organisation's head of residential research, Lucian Cooke, said: 'We expect growth to accelerate as affordability pressures ease, with the strongest growth forecast for 2027.'
Estate agency Knight Frank also said it expected growth from 2025 onwards in a forecast last month, with falls this year and next.

Experts said the reason prices will increase is likely to be a result of higher mortgage rates reducing housing affordability. Although rates are coming down, they could rise again given interest rates are expected to stay at their current level until at least mid-2024 at 5.25 per cent.
The higher interest rates are, generally the higher mortgage rates are, meaning there is less activity in the market as first-time buyers and movers look to hold off to see if rates reduce.
Should you aim to buy at the end of next year or start of 2025?
Though property prices are expected to reach their lowest level towards the end of next year, experts say you should be cautious about assuming this is the best time to buy.
'These forecasts can always change,' says Jonathan Rolande, founder of the National Association of Property Buyers.
'You might rush to buy then, or hold off and wait till then, and then find things change, and the forecasts say they won't actually reach their lowest point until a year later.'

Richard Donnell, executive director at property website Zoopla, agrees, and says that it 'can be very difficult to time a property purchase exactly with when prices are at their lowest point, particularly for a specific type of property in a specific area'.

Mr Rolande says buyers can be 'fairly confident' that significant price rises won't come in the next year, meaning if they are in the position to buy now, you are unlikely to lose out hugely if you do not buy immediately.
But he says that buyers also need to consider what they will do if they delay buying until then.

'I'd say if you're waiting until next year hoping prices fall, consider what the alternatives are - you might get your home for GBP 10,000 less in a year's time but then what if you've paid GBP 10,000 in rent. If you're happy to stay at home with mum and dad and save money, maybe it works. For others maybe it doesn't - it's all about personal circumstances.'
Mr Donnell agrees that holding off, or speeding up a purchase, to time it with when the market is cheapest may not work for many.

He says: 'If you're serious about living somewhere for 10 or 15 years, what's the point of holding off or speeding up to save a few thousand pounds? That price difference over a long period of time will be very small.'
Need to buy before then? Here's what to do
If you need to buy a home before the end of next year, Mr Rolande says there are several tips you can follow to ensure you get the best price.
First of all he says: 'Get all of things in order first - have your mortgage offers ready, have solicitors lined up. Try and explain and show to the owner why you are a good buyer.'

And what about keeping the price low. Mr Rolande says the key tip is: 'Never tell the estate agent you're prepared to offer more - remember the estate agent is working for the owner. Tell them the price you want to pay.'
Mr Donnell agrees that buyers need to make sure they're as clued up as possible.
He says: 'Do your homework - work out what the property you want to buy is worth. You can do this by looking at what has actually sold in the area that's similar to the property you are buying.'
This week, OBR published data showing mortgage rates are likely to remain high for the next six years.
It now forecasts that the average mortgage rate in 2025 is going to be 5 per cent, rather than just under 4 per cent it predicted eight months ago.
It says they will stay at 5 per cent, or around there, until 2026.
Some experts have forecast to Informfully that rates on mortgages will reduce in the coming weeks.
However, these are dropping from high levels and, relative to prices that households are used to in the past ten years, these will still be high.
In the near future, experts expect rates on 5-year fixes to possibly get below 4.5 per cent, before they increase in the longer term.
Two weeks ago, Andrew Montlake, director at Coreco mortgage brokers, said: 'I think we are seeing a mini rate war start, which will last the next two to three months.'
But back in the pandemic period, some people were able to secure mortgage rates of below 1  per cent.
With interest rates having risen from a low of 0.1 per cent in 2021 to a high of 5.25 per cent now, there is no indication that rates will return to these levels.

These means that even with rates now reducing from their current highs, those who have mortgages expiring in the coming year will likely pay hundreds or thousands of pounds more a month for their housing costs.

title: How to get a state pension if you've never paid National Insurance
lead: The amount people get as a weekly state pension usually depends on how many qualifying NI years they have over their lifetime
author: Callum Mason

body.text: People who have never made National Insurance (NI) contributions and those who do not have an NI number could still be entitled to a state pension under little-known rules.

The amount people get as a weekly state pension usually depends on how many qualifying NI years they have over their lifetime, with these being built up by either working and paying NI contributions, or by being awarded benefits and qualifying for NI credits.
But ex-pensions minister Steve Webb, now a partner at consultancy LCP, has established that there may people who do not fit this criteria who are entitled to a pension.
Since 2000, it has been a requirement to include a NI number to make a claim for Child Benefit, but prior to this date people did not have to supply one to make a claim.

This means that parents - most likely to be mothers - who claimed Child Benefit before this date could potentially be eligible for the credits which come with claiming it, but do not have an NI account to match them to.
Webb said this could have happened if someone entered the UK as an adult and never applied for an NI number.
He has helped one 68-year-old woman in this situation to get a state pension of over GBP 100 per week, when previously she was not getting one.
Ms D, who does not wish to be named, lives in Kent with her husband, an NHS doctor, and had a son born in 1982 and a daughter born in 1987, receiving Child Benefit for each.
As a result she is entitled to 'Home Responsibilities Protection' (HRP).
This is an old scheme, now replaced by NI credits, which allowed parents to build up entitlement to the state pension despite not working.
She is entitled to HRP from 198384 - the first full financial year after her first child was born - up to and including 200102 - after which her younger child turned 16.
People will need to apply forHRPif they think it's missing from their NI record.
Ms D had no NI number and no NI record but after help from Webb, was able to get one, get HRP added to her new NI account and could then claim a state pension.
She now receives a pension of more than GBP 6,000 per year and was able to make a backdated claim for the last 12 months.
Sir Steve's guidance for those in a similar situation who are not receiving a state pension is:

Webb said that for women whose entire NI record consists entirely of NI credits from time at home with children, the state pension will only be payable for those who reached pension age after 5th April 2010.
Before this date it was necessary to have paid one or more year of contributions to get a pension.

He said that it was difficult to ascertain exactly how many people will be owed a pension under the rules, but added that his guidance to anyone over pension age who is not getting a pension was to ring up and apply - even if they weren't entitled when they retired.
He added: 'There may be significant numbers of women who have been told that they are not entitled to a state pension because they do not have a NI record.

'Although it is a painstaking process, getting an NI number and then getting time at home with children credited to your NI account, this can be the gateway to a state pension. I would encourage any woman who has been told she is not entitled to a pension to explore this route.'

title: Third of teachers now retire early, losing GBP 4,500 a year from their pension
lead: 'The pressure of the profession' is pushing teachers out of the classroom despite the financial losses that come with this
author: Callum Mason

body.text: A third of teachers are losing thousands of pounds a year from their pension by taking early retirement.
Early retirement among teachers is at the highest level in five years - at 35.7 per cent - according to a data by the financial planning company Wesleyan Financial Services.

Its analysis of data obtained by a freedom of information request shows that a teacher who earns GBP 58,000 in their final year before retiring at 55 could lose around GBP 4,695 per year from their pension compared with retiring at 60.
Linda Wallace, a director at Wesleyan, said the increase in people retiring early suggests that more than ever, 'the pressure of the profession is pushing teachers out of the classroom.'

The Teachers' Pension Scheme (TPS) is a defined-benefit pension plan which means staff build up a guaranteed income each year in retirement based on their salary, rather than a pension pot which they must draw on in retirement.

The exact age at which teachers can draw on their pension varies depending on when they started their role, but it's generally, 60, 65, or State Pension age, which is currently 66. They can retire early, from 55, but will get less money paid out each year as they worked fewer years.
Cathy Styles, a retired headteacher from Cumbria, opted to take early retirement despite the financial hit.
Ms Styles,  retired at 58 and says she was 'very fortunate' to inherit a small amount of money that provided her with financial stability.

She estimates that her choice to retire early is costing her around GBP 2,000 to GBP 3,000 each year from her pension, but says the stress of the role meant there was 'no way' she could carry on working, citing increased pressure during Covid and in the immediate period afterwards.

'I can manage with what I have, though the loss is a very big hit. If I wanted to live in a little more luxury I would likely need more, but what I have from the inheritance is a financial cushion,' she said.

Former pensions minister Sir Steve Webb warned: 'Taking a pension early can be very attractive, especially to someone later in their career who would like to stop work.But this is not a decision that should be taken lightly.Where a pension is taken before the 'normal' age in the scheme, there is a reduction in the amount of pension you will receive and this can be quite substantial for those who retire well before the standard age.

Sir Steve, now a partner at consultants LCP, added: 'It is important to make sure that an entirely understandable desire to stop work early does not undermine your hope of a good quality of life and financial security in retirement.'
'Phased retirement' could be an option for many teachers

Teachers are able to reduce their working hours as they get older using a mechanism called 'phased retirement.' This means that they can work reduced hours or responsibility but keep working. During this time they can start cashing in some of their pension - to fund the part-time work - while still paying into it from their remaining salary to reduce the overall financial hit from early retirement.
But the data obtained by Wesleyan shows that just 3 per cent of retiring teachers last year took this option up.

Ms Wallace explained: 'Surprisingly few are aware of the phased retirement option that helps them ease into retirement more slowly. It also means they continue to earn a salary and keep contributing to the Teachers' Pension Scheme - growing their retirement income while reducing workload.
'For many teachers it's a great way to prepare for full retirement and it could be a better choice than leaving the profession altogether.'
The exact sums vary depending on your career, and how large the lump-sum you take in retirement is - but a calculator on the TPS website can show how much you will lose.
Phased retirement allows teachers to take up to 75 per cent of their pension benefits from the age of 55 while still working and paying into their pension.
To take this, teachers have to reduce their earnings by at least 20 per cent, which they can do by cutting their hours, or changing to a role that pays them less money.
As an example, someone who has worked in teaching for 30 years with an average salary of GBP 40,000 could take a pension of GBP 11,400 while still working.
However, not all schools will allow teachers to take this option, so some may need to look at a different employer to take it.
Ms Styles explains that she was aware of this option when she chose to retire, but opted not to take it.
She says: 'With headship, I figured out that if I reduced my hours to three days per week, what would happen would be that in reality I would work for five days, but get paid for three.'
But she adds that if she were in a classroom role she would have considered it, saying: 'I do think a lot of people should look at it as an option.'

title: Migrant labour curbs will stoke inflation and slow growth, angry businesses warn
lead: Business leaders attack new Government barriers to legal overseas workers for 'sending really bad signal around the world'
author: David Connett

body.text: Businesses reacted angrily to Government plans they say will make it harder for employers to hire overseas staff by raising the pay threshold for skilled workers and axing cut-price salaries in some sectors.

Measures include increasing the skilled worker earnings threshold by a third to GBP 38,700 as well as stopping employers being able to pay 20 per cent less than the going rate in areas where there is a skills shortage.
The changes, announced yesterday as part of efforts to cut net legal migration, were condemned by industry bodies for sending the 'wrong signal' about the UK as a place to do business.
Neil Carberry, chief executive of the Recruitment and Employment Confederation, called them 'wholly disproportionate'.
'The Government talks about wanting growth and increased productivity. Successful modern economies are international - but these changes will send the wrong signal around the world.
'They are wholly disproportionate, given that immigration for work in the private sector is such a small part of total immigration.
'From world-leading universities to globally competitive firms, attracting people to the UK for work and study is a benefit to growth and prosperity here.'
Mr Carberry said that firms would pay the price even as the Government 'chooses to exempt itself from the new threshold'.

'One rule for business, another for the public sector in health and care will not go down well with those in industry,' he said, adding: 'While many roles we have shortages in are driven by labour availability, the UK also has significant skills shortages.

'This news also underpins again the Government's serial failure to address the skills system despite half a decade of business feedback about the failed apprenticeship levy and the underfunding of further education.'

Alexandra Hall-Chen, a principal policy adviser at the Institute of Directors, said the plans would cause concern among businesses already struggling to recruit the labour they need, as well as fuelling inflation.

'We know that skills and labour shortages continue to be one of the top 'pain points' for businesses in the UK. Continued tightness in the UK labour market is feeding inflation and is a key reason that interest rates remain high,' she said.
'Without measures to increase domestic labour supply, policies designed to restrict businesses' ability to hire overseas workers risk worsening inflation and holding down economic growth.'

The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said that 'inflation-busting increases to minimum salary requirements and charges won't address the shortages that are currently holding back business investment and growth'.

Matthew Percival, the Confederation of British Industry's Future of Work Director, said: 'Businesses support the Government's objective to focus on productivity growth as the long-term answer to labour shortages.
'However, inflation-busting increases to minimum salary requirements and charges won't address the shortages that are currently holding back business investment and growth.

'Businesses strongly support the Shortage Occupations List and, if used correctly, it remains an important tool to help reduce acute labour gaps. They will also back the Government's decision to close the loophole that could allow firms to use foreign labour to undercut the salaries of UK workers.
'An honest conversation about immigration would focus on how visa rules best support economic transformation and sustainable growth, beyond short-term fixes.'

title: Thames Water owner could run out of money in 2024 as it insists supplies not at risk
lead: Britain's biggest water supplier faces 'uncertain' future as auditors warn 'no firm arrangements' in place for GBP 190m loan repayment
author: David Connett

body.text: The owner of Thames Water, the UK's biggest water company, risks running out of money next April if shareholders don't inject more equity into the debt-laden utility, its auditors have warned.

PricewaterhouseCoopers said there's 'material uncertainty' about whether the group can continue as a going concern due to question marks over the refinancing of a GBP 190m loan in one its subsidiary companies.

The auditors warn there is 'material uncertainty' over the water provider because of a loan repayment to Kemble Water Finance Ltd due for next April. Thames owner Kemble Water Holdings (KWH) say in the financial report they are confident the loan will be repaid but PwC said there were no firm arrangements in place to refinance a GBP 190m loan.

The auditors say that Thames' owners say they have a letter from shareholders indicating their future support for the company but point out the letter is 'not legally binding and there are no other firm commitments to refinance the loan'.

Thames is expected to face scrutiny over its debt levels when it issues results on Tuesday, as investors question the embattled company's financing structure. Parliament's Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee said it's considering calling executives in to explain whether they misled lawmakers about the company's financial situation when they gave evidence in July.
Ministers drew up contigency plans for the collapse of the water group after concerns that Thames might collapse under the extent of its debts.

Sir Robert Goodwill, chair of the committee, said it was considering a fresh investigation after reports that Thames Water had originally presented a loan from its shareholders to its parent as new equity funding.

Sir Robert has said that fresh financial disclosures had led the committee to 'question the accuracy of evidence provided to our committee by Thames Water in July'. It also 'raised further concerns about the stability of the company's finances and the actual ability of the company to invest the sums of money required to implement its turnaround plan', he said. 'Our committee will consider whether we need to call Thames Water back before us to explain how the evidence we heard stacks up against the recently reported revelations,' he added. Thames Water said it had not misled the committee.

In the financial report directors acknowledge there are 'material uncertainties' relating to refinancing requirements but said they have 'sufficient confidence' that Thames will 'maintain adequate resources to continue in operational existence'.

Ofwat, which only regulates Thames Water, which publish its half-year results on Tuesday, and not the parent company Kemble Water Holdings, has previously told Thames that they must address failures to meet water targets as well as strengthen their 'financial resilience.'

A Thames Water spokesperson said: 'We are in a robust financial position and are extremely fortunate to have such supportive shareholders. Our shareholders have already invested GBP 500m of equity in 2023.

'In addition, they have agreed to provide a further GBP 750m in new equity funding across AMP7. This further funding is subject to satisfaction of certain conditions, including the preparation of a business plan that underpins a more focused turnaround that delivers targeted performance improvements for customers, the environment and other stakeholders over the next three years and is supported by appropriate regulatory arrangements.

'Our shareholders have also acknowledged the need for additional equity investments indicatively in the region of GBP 2.5bn in Asset Management Period 8 (April 2025). In aggregate, this would equate to total equity investment of GBP 3.75bn, the largest equity support package ever proposed in the UK water sector.'

title: New savings account with Coventry offers 7%, but here's the catch
lead: Although it seems like a good deal, there are several caveats to be aware of
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: A new savings account is offering customers returns of 7 per cent a month on their funds, but there is a catch.
Coventry Building Society has launched the Loyalty Regular Saver account, a type of account that requires people to put money away each month with interest paid yearly.

While it does represent a good deal, there are some caveats to be aware of, including the fact that only savings or mortgage customers who have been with the society since 1 January, 2022 are eligible.
The account also only allows deposits of up to GBP 250 a month, meaning a maximum of GBP 3,000 can be saved in the year. The minimum balance is GBP 1.
If the maximum GBP 250 is saved each month, after 12 months, the total interest earned would be GBP 113.87.
Although the return is high, it is not the biggest return on regular savings with Nationwide offering 8 per cent and Skipton offering 7.5 per cent.
Both First Direct and Yorkshire Building Society are also offering 7 per cent.
Experts said it is a good rate but is only suitable for those willing to lock their money away.
Andrew Hagger of Moneycomms, said: 'Seven per cent is a very attractive rate in the current market, if you can afford to squirrel away the maximum of GBP 250 every month.
'But if you do make a withdrawal you'll lose 30 days interest on the amount withdrawn.
'On the Coventry website it clearly states this account is for savers not spenders.'
James Blower, founder of Savings Guru, added that if you have a lump sum of GBP 3,000 - the maximum that can be deposited - this could be better off elsewhere.
He said: 'If you do qualify, and you have spare money to save each month, then it is a no-brainer.

'However, if you have a lump sum of GBP 3,000 then don't be tempted to drip feed it in instead - putting GBP 3,000 in to the best easy access account will earn GBP 156 in interest at 5.2 per cent so this is a much better option, despite the lower rate.'
Coventry's Loyalty Regular Saver account can be opened online, in branch, over the phone or by post.
After 12 months, the account matures into the Society's Easy-Access Saver - a variable rate account which allows unlimited withdrawals and currently pays a rate of 3.1 per cent.
